Cult like management system. Stay away. Low pay... not up to industry standards. TNT merger a disaster. Toxic work environment. Lemming like mentality. I refrain from chastising the entire company. I hope it is just local issue (Gardena,CA) not a corporate Memphis issue... who knows?

pros:
Most of the time, depending on your manager at the time, you work with minimal supervision.  
     Meet many different types of people of different backgrounds.  
     Great opportunity for making new friends.  
     Flexibility to move around and earn extra hours in different departments.
     There many different short shift options, enabling flexibility to pursue things outside FX.
cons:
Over the past several years the health insurance FX offers has taken a drastic turn for the worse. 2014 is the worst yet. So much worse there has been consideration of whether to have it at all. 
     They used to provide excellent coverage, better than most other companies out there.  Now other companies far exceed.
     No raises over the past few years, except for certain "chosen" positions.
Reviews no longer have any impact on your a pay raise (if there were any).  No matter your performance now, everyone would receive the exact same percent.  A person of 20 years would receive the same percent as a 1 year worker no matter how good or bad you perform.  Raises based on performance reviews inspired people to work harder and strive.
No incentive to go above and beyond.
     Opportunity for advancement is low.  Policy does not favor advancement for those hoping to move up.  Positions for vertical movement have been slim, applicant pool high.  FX years of experience mean little to nothing in who receives the position.

review: little pay for a lot of work
pros: There are none to report
cons: There are no issues to make statement

review: Low pay and no room for advancement in my building.
pros: The benefits and perks are outstanding. The Fedex culture is great and the opportunities within the company as a whole are endless.
cons: Hourly/Operations employees are treated as second class citizens.

pros: always keeps you busy. never bored.
cons: micromanagement hell. expecting too much from too little

review: Fedex Sub contractor in San Leandro
pros: excellent Management and good team work
cons: Delivery truck need to update.

pros: The benefits are great compared to other companies.
cons: Lack of growth; ever-changing environment

review: Great place for a person that willing  to work hard
pros: Great pay once you put some time in. Benefit are very good. This is a job that no matter what level you are at you will likely have to hustle,  but it's nice to know that everyone is working as hard as you are and very few people have time to play around. I like my job because it is very interesting and no day is like the other.
cons: Starting out as a package handler is very hard work most can do it in short term but very few  have what it take to make a career of it. Moving up beyond a package handler with out a degree is very hard if not impossible in some facilities. I know some that have been with the company for over 6 years and still never made it past  package handler with a degree. They only want a certain type of person in managament rolls so if you don't fit the mold your out of luck.

pros: Schedule is not good there
cons: Pay is not good there

pros: Easy to learn and great co-workers
cons: Low pay and fast paced

pros: Great place to work at. Great management. Manager and supervisors are very friendly. They makde sure you work, but they don't push you to your limits, and they usually don't make you work overtime. Work is fast-paced, but not extremely fast. Do the best you can, don't stand around daydreaming and you'll be fine. If you're not used to activate work YOU WILL FEEL IT THE FIRST DAY, but after a day or two, your body will get accustomed to it and you'll barely feel a thing. Do wear protective gear: gripping gloves and FOREARM SLEEVES, I personally recommend the latter to avoid too much bruising. Pay is decent, and you get A LOT of good benefits even as a part-time employee, provided that you stay a while. If you're looking for a part- time job, LOOK NO FURTHER, FedEx is the place to be! Also worth mentioning, is how easy it is to get hired. I was hired after a week of attending a Sort Observation. When they call you back, show them that you're interested and you're basically in.
cons: Early AM Shift: Loss of sleep. Rough, tiresome first day. Not for the lazy.

pros: It is a Workout everyday
cons: Job can be tough on the body.

pros: Its decent pay for the work
cons: Having to keep up the hours

pros: None none none none none
cons: Waking up at 2am, hours are not guaranteed, pay is very low, and the work is extremely hard. Boxes are super heavy and no one helps you out. Not worth it.

review: A Lot Depends on Location & Managers - Some are Better than Others
pros: Easy to get hired.  Short shifts make it great for some people.   The pace is usually nonstop and intense, filling up the whole shift.  At our location, there is a core of very hard working people who assist and support one another.  You get benefits as a part time employee.
cons: You cannot live on this job alone.  The work is physical and demanding and can do some harm to your body.  The manager plays favorites and some people get away with doing as little as possible.  It is dirty and you are exposed to the elements in the winter.  Very little chance for advancement and not enough hours to support existence.  Peak Season can easily burn you out.

pros: I created friendships and a great mindset of hard work.
cons: It was a part-time job and the management didn't care to really hear about or help with any problems that were going on between employees under them.

pros:
good company 
weekly pay
cons: not available for comment at the moment

pros: There are no good pros for this company
cons: The hours are long and stressful

pros: Easy money you can make
cons: No hours hot work you hard

pros: Benefits, Pay, Coworkers, Environment, Management
cons: Environment, Schedule, Setting, Shifts, Ethic

pros: Treats employees well and with respect
cons: Sometimes too large of a corporation

review: Terrible place to work. Poor management.
pros: My coworkers are good people
cons: Too much work for $14.65 an hour

pros: FedEx is the best employer in the Memphis area among large companies.  You can work as hard as you want to.  The medical benefits are fair and unrivaled among companies in the area. The retirement programs are fair and effective if you use them.  Fred Smith is a great leader.
cons: I left after a 3 years when I found something better out of town.  The Legal department runs the company and is so risk averse that FedEx is way behind the curve in delivering solutions for customers.  The volatile prices of energy makes it difficult to plan project costs, and projects that are running great are frequently canceled because of cost reductions.  If you are in Services, there are not enough titles and salary bands are too wide to count on regular promotions.  IT's Directors and VPs are very weak leaders and there really isn't anyone among them that has a remarkable understanding of technology or business.  There are not enough young people at FedEx to learn from and cultivate them into leaders.  Memphis is an awful area to live and there's no talent to draw from it.

pros: Good wages and local management.  I would recommend FedEx to a friend and have.
cons: Some micro-management from upper management.  Benefits have lessened over the past few years and it is rare now to get 100% of bonus.  Usually attain between 25-50% now since they changed how it is paid out.  When I started 100 -120% attainment was considered normal.  It used to be based on station performance alone.  Now it is based on local, operating company performance, and corporate performance.  If FedEx decides to buy 100 new planes, it now affects your bonus.  I wouldn't mind the new structure as long as it was attainable.  Seems like they always have a reason for not paying out complete bonuses, even when then company is doing well.  We haven't come close to 100% since they changed it.

pros: 13.00 an hour was nice to earn
cons: had to stand for a long time

pros: Good health insurance.  Flexible work schedule.
cons: No direction or vision from leadership. Every new project or initiative is a top priority before finishing the previous top priority project or initiative. Bureaucry is more important than customers or innovation.

review: Great company to work for if you are looking to have balanced life/work environment.
pros: Workload is shared and many senior stuff members who can be good support system for junior stuff. Very stable company to work for as lay offs may be the last item on the CEOs list of cost cutting measures, he seems to care a bit about the employees.
cons: Wouldn't recommend for new college graduates who are still fresh & looking to develop their job skills quick as there's tendency to specialize in few job roles and not too exciting for workaholics, u may be bored with no work to do at times. Low stuff turnover, meaning very limited opportunities for growth to the next level.

pros: It exposes you to a variety of environments.
cons: Not based on a set schedule

pros: They provide Coffee, Tea, Water, Elevators, and Restrooms
cons: Poor Management, Lack of communication, Prehistoric procedures

review: A great company going through some tough times
pros: You work with a great team, the salary and benefits are excellent.  They almost always promote from within, although the road getting there can be pretty tough (as it should be).  You really get to have an impact on your employees' lives, and you can feel like you're part of a family if you stick around long enough.
cons: No home life whatsoever.  Some very hard choices have to be made at the end of the fiscal year when suddenly budgets shrink and everyone at the corporate level wants you to do more with less.  High octane, high stress environment with little to no downtime.  They give you a laptop and a cell phone and you had better be attached to them 24/7.  High turnover rate among managers, who seem to get fired extraordinarily easily.

pros: Flexibility based on your sales manaager. Great benefits and travel perks.
cons: Lack of work life balanace. Management keeps piling more into the sales reps, constant delusion of revenue due to current market for shipping

pros: Good pay but much required
cons: Much red tape with no reason

review: Multi-tasking, fast-paced, personable, but often too stressful
pros: Very inclusive company, positive working environment, encourages teamwork and has solid ethical enforcement. Management is selected well. Build consistent and positive relationships with regular customers, and really feel like you're helping them out with high-priority situations, from important shipments to wedding invitations and funeral memorials.
cons: Often understaffed to meet customer needs; multiple customers in different parts of the store, all needing your help at the same time when you're understaffed and have deadlines to meet for shipping AND printing needs -- very stressful. Customer Service doesn't communicate consistent protocols that retail stores need to operate under. Job is already stressful enough as is with so much multi-tasking involved, but then you're also expected to push sales of specific items each month, plus packing services (when you sometimes don't even have proper time to package items).

pros:
Great work life balance. Sr Mgmt encourages a lot of community work. 
Good pay. Cost of living is pretty low compared to major cities. Pay hikes are pretty low. 
Interesting Business problems. Constantly changing economic landscapes has us doing a lot of analytics to support business decisions. Strong analytics forms the backbone of a number of group in fedex.
Lot of focus on employee training and developing leadership. Management is very friendly and easily accessible. every major life event (marriages, birthdays, babies) are celebrated with a lot of joy. Lot of ongoing community work during office hours as part of corporate responsibility.
Very diverse culture - lots of women and minorities in the work place.
cons:
Career growth can be slow. Very few mgmt openings and too many professionals vying for them.
Company pursues too many projects and there are lot of resource issues.The operate independently model hampers a lot of initiatives. The hierarchy is pretty flat at the top and lot of issues cannot be resolved by top management due to the flat structure.
very different cultures across opcos.

review: Good if you don't like free time
pros: The company had very little minorities years ago. Now that's pretty much all they hire which isn't a bad thing equal opportunity is very important so before when a select few could apply now it's open to everyone
cons: They tell you work and life will be balanced but here always short staff cutting hours and hiring kids right out of high school who see one take the job seriously so if you show any sign of being a good worker they'll call you every day off bug you non stop and if you tell them know you'll find your schedule being altered or "adjusted" to fit the world flow regardless. It starts off cozy then once you warm up to people you learn it's a colony you can't tell them no I've work 60 hour weeks 3 weeks in a row I'd like a day off. high drama and gossip a lot of managers have been in place since the 70s and 80s a lot of 20+ year vets that have a hard time connecting with newer generations that leads to trash talk behind their backs and other petty actions I wish I can say this is just 1 out of a few stores but I've worked as a team memeber and a manager at pretty much 7 out of 11 Boston stores and it's just about the same.

pros: Easy and fun ppl to work with
cons: 150 dollar checks and lazy managers

review: This should not be your first choice
pros: Large cubicle size, travel opportunities, flexible vacation and sick day scheduling, maternity leave
cons: Large amount of technical debt, no long term strategy, poor communication, no technical position advancement, some micromanagement

review: A great company to be at!
pros: There isn't much I can't say! I've never worked for a company this amazing. I've had a lot of different jobs and coming to Fedex has been a beautiful wake up. This will be the place I retire from. 'The FedEx way' was shown to me the first two weeks in the door. 99.9 percent of people I have met have been nothing but kind and love their jobs! Resources are everywhere and encouraged to use! This company treats you like family and has strong family values. Positive encouragement is passed out on a regular basis and negativity is not welcome. The benefits are outstanding! Management and above listens to everyone and your effort is appreciated. The team activities are fun and never feel forced. I am so grateful to be part of the Fedex family. If you have the chance - don't miss out!
cons: Pay is a little low for the field. The interview process can be overwhelming and can make you almost walk away. Don't! The cons really aren't here. If the pay was a tad higher I think this company would literally be the top company to work for!

pros:
benefits
growing opportunities
helpful managers
increase wages
food and water supplies
cons:
hard work
not enough hours
Very hot or cold
too much pressure to work

review: Still absolutely, positively after all the years
pros: Company culture is great, very positive towards customers and employees. We're all in it together. The old "absolutely, positively" ethic is still alive at FedEx. Cost of living is low compared to pay for the Memphis area locations. Benefits are good, especially work life balance. My manager always says, "Work to live, don't live to work." FedEx is one of the largest shipping companies in the world, so we get to work on some of the largest, most interesting business challenges in the world.
cons: FedEx (and its divisions) are a very large, mature company. Bureaucracy is the norm for large companies. It is easy to get lost in the masses. Advancement opportunities can be hard to find in many parts of the corp, unless you have a senior manager champion who wants you promoted. There is an entrenched good-old-boy network which can be hard to crack. Look out if/when Fred Smith retires.

pros: Great company. I was proud to work for them. However, I think it is built on the back of the couriers, pilots, and hub people and delivers packages on time despite current poor IT support.
cons: The company has become mired in the mud due to new processes implemented over the last few years. It is impossible to get anything done for the users. Small fixes take an act of Congress to load to production, much more than they are worth. So anything but the most fatal of errors is never scheduled for work. Paperwork occupies most of a developers time. Don't go there if you like to make things *work* for your users.

review: No Future as a Dock Worker
pros: Great Pay, Great benefits, Great perks.
cons: Dock Workers are treated like trash.

pros: The people are amazing. Management really cares about their people, helping them to learn and grow. What you think is really hard is not. I left seeking more money. I work twice the hours with less appreciation and the work is so much harder. At some point you have to decide what is important. If it is family and security with work/life balance and a place that encourages great customer service and volunteerism - stay at FedEx! I had 6 weeks vacation that I was encouraged to use. I will never ever get that again.
cons: When you have been here for 10 years you see other, "newer models" coming in and making more money than you do. It is really discouraging. All I wanted was market value for my hard work and couldn't get it. They backfilled my position, turned over two people and then ended up paying more than what I asked for.

pros: Excellent brand that gets you in the door with companies you call upon. Also helps to have the FedEx name at your back when you have to prospect for new business.  You have the ability to plan your days the way you want around your schedule, so work life balance is great.  The relationships you build are great because you're helping people with their business.  Competition is usually FedEx vs UPS.  Plenty of opportunities if you want to move around in the company.
cons: Onboarding is really poor. The training you receive is good on a corporate level, but there's so much to learn that it's a 'trial by fire' mentality while learning from your other reps in the area.  their plate is full, too, so if you don't have any team players, you could be screwed. It's a general consensus that you don't feel remotely comfortable until at least a year on the job. Expectations of calls per day is not set in stone, but it might come up if you're not performing and consistently closing business. If you thrive off of a team atmosphere and interaction with team members, this is not the job for you.  Perform or they won't hesitate to manage you out.

pros: everything is unbelievable here at fed ex
cons: I have no cons to offer at this moment

review: Good Company but very slow growth as a technology company
pros: Great company to work if you like work life balance.  The benefits used to be great many years ago, but its not too bad now either.  The salaries are very standard.  They pay enough for the kind of jobs they have.  If you are a software engineer who has enough skills to get by programming languages, understand a few design patterns, have basic knowledge of software engineering and prefer a laid back work environment, so you can have enough time for family this is the place to be.
cons: If you are highly innovative and spirited as an engineer, this place is a total letdown.  FedEx is a transporation based company, not a technology company.  Their ideas in innovation are still dated and go real slow in releasing the latest and greatest of products.  Their business model is highly process based, even though some departments take pride of releasing new products as services to existing customers.  Just as any large company, FedEx also has a lot of red tape and bureaucracy.  If you work in the company for a long time, you will be in the dangerous zone of letting your skills become obsolete or unused.  You have to make an effort on your own to stay up to date with the industry.

pros: It is like being part of a professional sports team at FedEx Ground. Management doesn't force too much down your way, but you are an essential cog of the wheel. It is an easy job to get, but it takes art and strength to keep it past even the trial period. If you get good and do it correctly, it is a great exercise.
cons: The primary position requires that you scan 300 barcodes an hour and lift 70 lbs. quite regularly and if you can't take that you will not be around long. Most people actually do make it. There are sirens and the constant noise of the conveyor, earplugs might save the valuable hairs of your inner ear.

pros:
-Looks good on your resume.
-Able to make more decisions.
-It‚Äôs what you want out of it if you just want the min that‚Äôs what you will get. If you want more you will have to step up and get it.
cons:
-Turn over rate is horrible.
-People call in all the time.

review: Eye opening to what not to do when running a business
pros:
Previously the health insurance was pretty good, however I have heard it changed for the worse.
The tuition reimbursement program
The regular employees were amazing...management needed some work
cons: An example of how a greedy company buys/acquires another and attempts to take away everything unique about it and turn it into the same type of business as every other office store in America gone completely wrong. FedEx attempted to completely rebrand Kinko's and in my opinion has failed miserably at it, cost themselves so much revenue expanding and offering overpriced retail products customers can find elsewhere for  a fraction of the cost. After failing to meet revenue goals due to the excess revenue spent cleaning up their mess take it out on their employees by getting rid of salary increases and cutting hours.

review: Not a great company to work for
pros:
Good benefits
Some nice people to work with for the most part
They got rid of the person in charge that was ruining the company, sent her to Hawaii
cons:
Pay is not that great for all the work we have to do and things we have to know
Raises are very low, few and far between'
Recognition doesn't happen much
Poor choice for people chosen as  managers and team leads
Morale is non-existent

pros: Growth opps are available
cons: Not willing to hear employee feedback. No hr on site.

review: It's okay to make money for a whileYou can get
pros: Alright pay , some days are fast
cons: You can get hurt physically from driving and the packages being extremely heavy

pros: Can‚Äôt really think of anything that would make me want to go back.
cons: If you love to be micro managed and treated like Crap. This is the place for you.

pros: The location of the company.  Job is ok.
cons: Old school mentality.  People-Service-Profit is not always a prime focus.  Talk about inclusion and diversity, let's talk about paying diverse people fairly.

review: Great place to work with a lot of flexibility
pros: Lots of flexibility on hours, relocation, and promotion.  Generally good people and a world-class service brand.  I had worked for the "major competitor" for many years, and found the FedEx workplace and culture to be much more open and motivated.
cons: Work ethic tends to be somewhat lax.   Customer service is given a lot of lip service, but many employees and managers find excuses to cut corners at the expense of the customer.   Training is somewhat lax, and employee performance could be improved if methods and accountability were of a higher standard.   But again, I came from "the Other Company" where standards were higher....  The best employees at FedEx are those who are self-directed and have high personal standards.  Management won't hold you to high standards unless they themselves have them.

review: Management is clueless at times and doesnt care.
pros: Great benefits and nice coworkers
cons: Its all about who you know to advance. Family work life balance is nonexistent.

pros: There are many different groups in IT, so you can learn a variety of things by switching jobs within the company (but if the budget is frozen, you're stuck).  Stable job, you're not likely to get fired or laid off.  Good benefits.  Tuition reimbursement.  On-site classes by staff as well as vendors.  On-site gym and cafeteria.  The tech campus is located in a quiet residential area.  Some groups have a laid-back atmosphere, I see people having 6-hour work days and getting away with it.  However, there are teams that have strict deadlines and 70-hour work weeks.  It really depends on which group you're in.
cons:
I have heard that it is difficult to move up the ladder in the technical direction, so many people go into management to be able to advance their careers.  Sometimes policies such as time off and working from home are not clear, things are often done by personal arrangement with the manager.  
If you are a conservative married middle-aged Southern American, you'll feel right at home at FedEx.  If that description does not apply to you, you might have difficulty trying to fit in socially.  Again, this depends on your particular team, but if you're unlucky enough to be the opposite of this description, be prepared for the possibility of social isolation and fear of expressing your individuality.

review: One of the best big companies to work for
pros: FedEx people are pleasant to work with. The company does things to offer a lot of training and development for its employees. They put more into training and development than other company I've worked for. They also are very diverse and believe in putting high quality people in positions to succeed. The benefits are also excellent, particularly if you live in Memphis.
cons: To move far up the ladder, you'll have to live in Memphis, TN at some point. And if you're from a big city environment, or like having lots of cultural things to do, you probably won't be thrilled to live there. However, if you tend to throw your life into your work, then that might be a good thing because you won't have many distractions (if you're from a small town or like a slower pace of life, it's perfect). The company is also conservative, bureacratic, methodical, and tends to move slow. If you are used to fast-paced, wheeling and dealing companies where you don't need multiple levels of approvals for things, then this might not be for you.

pros: Salary and potential to earn weekly bonuses
cons: Long hours worked and wear and tear on body. High expectations

pros: Amazing benefits go well beyond health care, includes 24/7 Nurse on call. Also work/Life Balance counselors. Too much to list here.  Retiree benefits are also wonderful as long as you are 55 yrs. and have 20 yrs with company. Make a career with FedEx and you can be financially secure when you retire. Part time employees entitled to healthcare benefits, 401k, pension and life insurance just as full time employees. Great opportunity for growth and movement throughout the company and the country should you ever want to relocate.
cons: Shift work in certain positions that can be very disruptive to healthy sleep. No time off during "Peak" season. Generally Dec 1, through Dec 26.  Also when you have off for a Holiday,  generally scheduled to work much earlier the day after because freight is behind by a day. If you are young and looking for a career with security, growth and very fair wages,  FedEx is worth looking in to. Older people and disabled not so much.

pros: Simple job, good hours, decent managers
cons: No room for growth or very little

pros: Good hours for family time if you know the area
cons: Poor communication for part time

pros:
- Being able to work from one store to another sometimes.
- Nice uniforms. That was nice.
cons:
- 3-4 People can NOT handle a store on their own--especially in a congested area. We never had enough people to work on the floor
- We were expected to print, ship, AND provide sales on the floor. We had to clean our own bathrooms and try to provide customer service to those who want to print things on their own. It's IMPOSSIBLE.
- I remember being opening a store with my assistant manager and having 15+ people needing our assistance. Again. That is IMPOSSIBLE because we also provide print services. So we will have these long lines because we're working with customers that would require 15+ minutes of our time to assist them. Then we go and have to ship things for other customers. THEN we have to handle angry customers because they're waiting 30+ minutes just to buy a notebook. It's ridiculous and stressful and just. Ugh. It has been three years since I set foot to work in a Fedex store and it STILL was traumatic. I cried driving up there one time it was that bad.
- I didn't have proper training but was expected to just "figure it out" when dealing with customers placing a print order.
- Think twice about working in the retail store; or just don't do it.

pros: Puts employees FIRST. I love that the founder makes it a priority to recognize the employees as being the reason for company success. Several perks, and programs are available to ensure we are taken care of. Pay is good, morale is good! I am still considered a ‚Äúpuppy‚Äù with ‚ÄúONLY‚Äù 17yrs here!! There is a reason folks stay- we bleed purple. Amazing company to work for. It‚Äôs an honor and privilege!
cons: Very hard to be a remote employee in IT because it isn‚Äôt the norm in the dept I am in. I do understand that I have to work even harder to stay visible- but that also means my manager and team also needs to make sure they include me in communications and meetings. Kinda hard to be involved if I‚Äôm not being told what‚Äôs going on... but it‚Äôs still new to allow remotes, so I‚Äôm sure it will get better

pros: Good benefits and pay. Can be a rewarding job.
cons: Not all managers were honest and there is problems with favoritism.

pros: Benefits, PTO, Sick Days are great
cons: Management ideas do not trickle down

review: Quality Driven Management - Make it Work!
pros: Fred Smith knows what he's doing.  He has based FedEx on the People-Service-Profit premise that if you take care of your people, they will provide the service needed and the profit will come.  He actually wants to take care of his employees and customers.
cons: Unfortunately, too many in management/senior management are more interested in their next promotion or how to obtain a 5-Star than they are in doing right things right the first time.  Fred's renewed emphasis on Quality is falling on deaf ears in the management and senior management ranks.  They are using the ready-fire-aim method rather than assess-build-launch-evaluate.

pros: Great pay for the area. I am very happy with how I am treated at FedEx. FedEx has a pension plan that is very nice. The pension plan is a portable pension plan, which means I keep it even if I leave the company; however, I have no plans to leave. The IT market in Memphis is very poor right now. I feel lucky to be at FedEx during such hard times. Hilton, Internation Paper, Service Master, and Harrah's Entertainment all seems to making big cut backs, including layoffs. It seems that the only IT jobs left in Memphis are contract jobs.
cons: It is hard to make a name for yourself and stand out. Great pay for the area. I am very happy with how I am treated at FedEx. FedEx has a pension plan that is very nice. The pension plan is a portable pension plan, which means I keep it even if I leave the company; however, I have no plans to leave. The IT market in Memphis is very poor right now. I feel lucky to be at FedEx during such hard times. Hilton, Internation Paper, Service Master, and Harrah's Entertainment all seems to making big cut backs, including layoffs.

review: Ethical company poised for continued growth
pros: If you are willing to move to Memphis, there are lots of opportunities to grow your career.  The leadership team is made up of employees who grew through the ranks so they know the business intimately and can relate to employees. I really like the senior leadership team -- they are ethical and easy to talk to because they listen to you regardless of your position in the company.
cons: They are very slow to move sometimes and it feels like everything down the most minute internal memo requires legal review. There is a distinct "Memphis-centric" sense to the mid-level business partners - as though if you are out in the field, you need to prove yourself that much harder because they are skeptical that anybody else can do what they do.

pros: The people you work with are laid back
cons: the work load is intense

pros: Allowed Flexible Hours and days of week to work
cons: Unsupportive management and training advancement structure

pros: Learn how to work hard
cons: No appreciation for hard work

pros: Great benefits and flexible hours
cons: Sometimes weather can be hard to adjust

pros: Good benefits and work life balance

pros: Cool management and hectic vibe
cons: Not flexible and super tiring

pros: It‚Äôs okay job  very low key

pros: Im my honesty opinion i do love the company, I'm able to get my products before the delivery ( because i work there), shipping is Much Cheaper, great environment, management is understanding and willing to actually work with you in almost any situation thinkable, were always changing and updating things, food parties if we have a good week and since I'm still in school working at night is a god send because i have all day to myself. If you love to workout this place will give you a good workout. but the best thing about this place is that they choose workers for management before looking outside the company!!
cons: probably could be a bit better pay for certain situations ( taking on multiple rolls in the company like me), and making the environment a little more fun i guess you could say (more so making the workers feel better as they work)

review: Decent company but leadership & resources lacking
pros: It is the largest customs brokerage, decent hours, interesting projects.
cons: Leadership is lacking.  Do not get most federal holidays off.  Good old boy network.

pros: There is a good Work life balance, culture
cons: Favoritism, if you're manager isn't good you will struggle

review: FedEx services- challenging job with the potential for earnings
pros: Great earnings potential, Sales Professionals have one of the top jobs within the Corporation.
cons: Tremendous responsibility to your customers and the company. Change is Constant.

pros: Can't really think of any.
cons: The worst company I have ever had the displeasure of working for! The nepotism and cronyism are so vapid, that promotions, advancing to other departments are non-existent. People abuse 'working from home' and 'traveling' they never have to use their vacation days, because all they have to say is that they are WFH. Meanwhile, the people who are doing most all the grunt work are required to sit there from 9-6 watching others come and go as they please (example: they come in at 10am and leave around 2pm and yes, they take a lunch too). If someone is ever so privileged to have the title "manager" they get to do even less. Zero communication, which leads to constant chaos and stress. No dress code, people often dress like it is a Friday night club. Zero professionalism all around. When corporate comes to visit, they send emails (to about half of the company) telling them to dress up and show up to work. The company was started by some frat brothers so you can imagine the atmosphere. People walk around the office with their speakerphones on, other times they yell at each other (carry conversations) across the room rather than get up and talk or email. Some departments are grossly underpaid, meanwhile, new hires (friends and family) get a hefty payday. The building is disgusting nasty stains all over the carpet.

pros: You get a check every week.
cons: Management treats you like your in the milltary...weekend work assigned at last minute, you cannot plan a single weekend, because you never know if your working. Poor Managment!!!!!!

pros: Good benefits and decent pay
cons: Hours were unpredictable and were forced to do different positions without much training

pros: I love the work. It's like getting paid to exercise. After you hit 1,000 hours, you qualify for very inexpensive, very awesome health, vision and dental benefits. After 3 months of employment you have access to PTO, which is pretty great. It's very laid back in terms of work attire (you can basically wear anything you'd like) and I like that it's kind of a "locker room" environment in the hub. No one is going to bat an eye if you drop the F bomb. Lol.
cons: Not a very liveable wage, and outside of peak season the hours can be very meager and inconsistent. If they have to many people and not enough packages, they start sending people home early for the shift/sort. It can be very hard on the body, very dangerous and rigorous.

review: One of Memphis' best employers, rated in the top 100 places to work in IT
pros: co-workers are great, immediate management is good, health benefits are good for a family
cons: salary is lower here than other parts of the country due to a bit lower cost of living, benefits are slowly being chipped away at, some subtle, traditional pension no longer offered, first ever pay cut in 2008 of 5% (more counting no bonus and no 401K matching that was stopped for a while) never restored despite better company performance a few years later.  jumpseat flying taken away.  parts of the city and some surrounding suburbs are going downhill as the city annexes more areas

pros: 10 years ago FedEx was a place I was proud to contract trucks with.  It WAS a fun place to work.  The memory includes decent pay, a tire discount program, a maintenance program with bonuses.  and a decent run schedule.
cons:
Every year the FedEx  contract has taken from us.  We were forced to put workers comp on contracted drivers. FedEx never gave us revenue to cover this cost.  We were forced to make contracted drivers OUR employees.  FedEx didn't compensate us for the additional costs. The tire program was cancelled, The maintenance program with bonuses was cancelled.  I'm sure the fuel cards, fuel tax program and toll transponders are the next to go.  
  If you have an accident FedEx Ground will almost always say it was your fault.  Even if it goes to court and you win.  I've seen this happen.
   One of the drivers had prostrate cancer.  FedEx tried to disqualify him after his doctor ok'd him to return to work.  He's back to work but only after FedEx Ground was threatened with a law suit.   Local management is an embarrassment and disgrace..

pros: Company has really good benefits
cons: Not much to grow in the tech support department

pros: Good compensation and great work life balance.
cons: Middle management does not have a clear vision

pros: The brand is second to none, the service is second to none and the employees are second to none.  Our customer are top priority from the janitors to the CEO.  We all share the same vision and as a result we are able to focus on our customers.  I would be willing to bet that if asked every single employee could tell you what their purpose is and why.  I would also be willing to be that the answer would always end with a customer driven purpose.  We know why we are here.  It isnt about us.
cons: It is a very long day. When you strive for perfection which the company and the employees do there are frustrating moments when something goes wrong.  Weather, technology blips.  We dont want unsatified customers.  We are in the business of delivering packages not bad news.  We have long days because we want the customer to be able to go home on time.

pros: You get to become connected with the business community and go behind the scenes to see what goes on in the warehouse, on the dock, manufacturing areas, production, etc.  Very fascinating stuff goes on behind otherwise normal looking front doors.
cons: Enormous bureaucracy  - it's very difficult to make progress.  No career progression unless you want to move to Memphis.

pros:
Good Health insurance coverage and price. About $400/mo for Kaiser, dental and vision for family coverage.
Pretty good compensation for the work.  Chances for advancement, if you have a flexible schedule.  Ability to transfer to different locations.  Advancement seems to have slowed down, due to FedEx being a mature company, and slowing of business.  There do seem to be a lot of people that have been there 20-25 years, so there may be better chances of advancement in the near future.  Good place for people without a degree to make an okay living.  Good for people looking for part-time and benefits.  Company has matching 401k and pension plan.
cons: Can be difficult scheduling vacations, days off.  Having to work holidays. Varied schedule.  Vacations needs to be scheduled a year in advance and taken in 5 day blocks, which makes it difficult to schedule days off if you have kids involved in activities you want to go to.  Time off is based on availability and seniority.

review: Overall, working with the IT group was a miserable experience. Company overall is very good.
pros: The company overall is very generous. Benefits were great. Everyone I worked for was great and very helpful. Company has a great reputation both inside and outside
cons: The department I worked for under the IT group (specifically the QA Department) was less than desirable. Uncertainty on my job role & function, micromanaging and the inability to move out from under the SVP made life miserable. I was hired in by a manager who was new and didn't know what his role was nor did he know exactly what my role was. The result was a 'sink or swim' environment that resulted in being in survival mode in the world of a monster company. I will never forget what it means to be in 'the belly of the beast' working for this company.

pros: Benefits are good, pay not so much.
cons: Poor pay, high work load, highly political and volatile environment.

pros: Non waste of time
cons: pushing to hard to pick up packages, violating speed limits, and parking laws

review: Not Bad! Easy to get job!
pros: Easy Application, Quickly hired you after observation and fill the application, All of you will get hired no matter what if you have experience or not but important that you have a transportation to work from home. Flexible with schedule or you can arrive late but you must call advance one hour prior work start! Awesome!
cons: Last minutes to informs you the schedule to start work, Manager will yelled at you daily, push you to rush & work hardest.  Hell to work! Because you will have to pick up 0.01 lbs- 150lbs or more.  Very strict with tardy and absent if you do. Possible to get termination or ask you resign.

pros: The work is quite simple most of the time. You get to set your own pace, work as hard as you want and finish early; or take your time and cruise through the day. It really depends on the location, or the boss you work for, but most of the time, the workload is fairly reasonable. Also, most of the actual job takes place outdoor, so that can be a positive or negative depends on the person. The pay was fair for the work involved, and most of the time the equipment are well maintained and suited for the job. The job also doesn't demand much of customer interaction if you're not comfortable doing that kind of things.
cons: The workload is very erratic, there's almost never a normal workday; especially around the holidays. The time you start actually working depends very much on the people who work in the office and handle your paperwork. A majority of time, you will be working by yourself, so if you run into any problem, it's usually all up to you to solve it.

pros: Easy work, kind of like a work out really
cons: Depending on the volume hours can range from 2-4

pros: people, freedom, no boss, work at your own pace
cons: hours, pay, no benefits, management

pros: Nothing no advancement long morning meetings
cons: Short hours miserable staff and coworkers

review: Could be a great job if you know what you are getting in to...
pros: In sales, there is a relative sense of job security even when you are not that good.  There are nice benefits like car stipends and insurance.
cons: If you really want to succeed you simply must become like those above you.  While they may say they want people who "think-outside-the-box" I really don't think they really understand what that means.  Senior management in the -+55 age range are stifling growth and causing real talent to leave.  They would rather you go through the formalities and become a box checker as opposed to questioning why things are done how they are.  They are building the future based on the ideas of the past that have succeeded with no variation for today's world.  Middle management lacks any real backbone when it comes to allowing senior management to understand what is really going on.  You can come in as a great thinker with great ideas but you will soon see others getting promoted simply because they are more like the person above them.  The performance review is really somewhat of a joke.

pros: Pay is pretty good I'd say
cons: Tough work. Lots of things to do

review: Great place overall but is becoming too slow to react and very resistant to change.
pros: Very good life/work balance, good benefits and interesting work.
cons: FedEx is no longer a young company but it has not yet learned how to deal with its age. Most decisions are still made very high up. It becomes increasingly difficult to acomplish anything due to lots of red tape and bureaucracy behind which a lot of incompetent MDs and VPs are hiding. Worse, very rarely anyone is punished for poor performance or failed projects. All that makes promotions slow and a lot of great people leave due to lack of opportunities.

review: Small fish in a very big pond... you are just a number here.
pros: There are some and always have been some great people that work at this company. I have built some long and lasting relationships with many of them.
cons:
For more than a decade this company has had a high rate of turnover and their management is well compensated when their employees are downsized and given pay cuts. The company has a good year and employees dont get a bonus and have even received pay cuts. This company goes through predictable cycles of a few good years and then a few bad years revenue wise. The troubles all come from management - they are arrogant and not focused. They tell you how important the culture is at this company but they are telling you this from their rather large ivory towers.

Don't be fooled this company has no loyalty to you... 99% of the 30+ people I know that used to work there have moved on to better jobs elsewhere with more pay and more opportunity. While 99% of the people I know that still work there are in the same jobs or only made lateral moves or one bump in position. Good place to just collect a paycheck that will never change.

pros: Good pay, Overtime, benefits, paid time off
cons: Hostile environment, favoritism, extra heavy workload, very stressful

pros: The benefits are pretty good compared to other companies.  The insurance is good.  The pension has been changed twice in the last five years, but at least we have one.  If you are in the field you have a great opportunity to satisfy your customers.  You can build relationships and run your job like it is your own business.  There is a no layoff policy, although it is not written in stone.  The senior mgmnt. is invisible to people in the field.  There is no one looking over your shoulder when you do your job.  If you are a courier you are outside most of the time.
cons: This is a two tiered company.  Management vs. hourlies.  The frontline employees are viewed with utter contempt.  The managers micromanage everything.   The managers are kool-aid drinkers and many believe anything upper management tells them even when it makes no sense.  The benefits have slowly been whittled away from us.  No more profit sharing, no jumpseat benefit, no survivor income benefit, no Individual performance pay.  If you have surgery and go out on disability you get five sick pay days and then you have to go on STD. The vendor for Fedex treats you like a criminal.  Fedex chooses the low cost provider for benefits.

review: If you like to keep your head down this is a good place.
pros:
Job stability -- very difficult to lose one's job here.
401(k) employer match is decent.
Health insurance was ok, getting worse with consumer health plan in '14
If you work in a well-managed port, things can be really great.
cons:
Too fragmented and different modes don't speak the same language.
Some managers are too divorced from operations and make odd or silly decisions.
HR is out to lunch and some egregious employee behavior is not addressed timely.
Job descriptions don't match actual duties resulting in underpaid and overworked staff.
Compensation is too low for the level of knowledge required to do most jobs.
Training is not a priority despite the increasing demand for compliance by CBP, lots of out of pocket expenses to get the training needed to advance.
Antiquated computer systems - 20 yrs is too long to go without a major update.

review: Great job but not for everybody.
pros: When I got this job it was simply a part-time job to make ends meet right after I had my wife had our first child. With that being said, it was a great job and if you are a hard worker that shows up on time you are definitely appreciated and provided with ample opportunity to move up within the company, probably more so than any place I have ever worked.
cons: I said that it was a great job, and it is, but it certainly isn't for everyone. I was a part-time package handler and I was offered a full-time position fairly quickly. As a package handler you load or unload trucks, that are dusty as all get out, it hot and cold environments, depending on the season. The dust probably bothered me more than the heat, I'd come home and blow black snot out of my nose on a regular basis. Still a good job though.

pros: Independent work, time goes by fast, pension, insurance benefits, tuition reimbursement, can transfer anywhere in the country, lots of internal jobs to transfer into, great for a college student because of the 2nd shift jobs and tuition reimbursement.
cons: At the courier level, the job is only as good as the management. Most of the managers I have worked for have been extremely unprofessional. I suspect they are being asked to do impossible tasks, and it seems most of them can't handle the pressure when they pass on their requirements to the couriers. The managers are rude, impossible, inflexible, revengeful, and play favorites to the point where it makes the job not worth working there. Upper management does not deal with unprofessional management at the operations level effectively. Inept managers are allowed to retain their job for decades rather than remedial training, or termination. New employees who are hired as couriers will never make what I make now because fedEx has implemented a two-tier wage system. It's impossible for a new hire to ever top out. Only lip service is paid to improving the work process and environment through employee input. employees are simply told what to do whether the command has been thought through thoroughly or not.

pros: Due to its long term success and market leadership the company is overall hesitant to change out of a fear that the tech is too complicated modify. For the right professional this is an excellent business  opportunity to innovate. The core business satisfies a basic public need, and the business is simple in that it is about delivering a package as quickly as possible whether its a letter or shamu the whale
cons: An understandable hesitation to change exists regardging working systems fro day operations. Even as there are aging technologies in some areas. the general managment attitude is a reluctancy to consider improvements due to complex embedded proprietary business methods

pros: Good benefits and good hours
cons: Cheap pay and not enough incentives

pros: Very Physical.  You'll stay in shape.  part time and seasonal
cons: low pay. mediocre management.  unrealistic expectations

review: Great if You Live in memphis
pros: Good healthcare and benefits. Relatively good job security as long as you do your job at a half competent level (i.e. they don't really fire anyone). Good willingness to embrace a healthy work-life balance.
cons: Management is hit or miss. Many of the managers seem to people who have just been around long enough that they've been promoted because they have the most seniority. Team building and incorporating remote workers into work groups is a challenge that is given LOTS of lip service, but no real support.

review: Excellent, great company to work for
pros: Focus on people, work/life balance, opportunities to rotate and grow, hire/promote from within, healthy team environment in most teams I have seen, good benefits, strong/stable company, very well managed (which  I particulatly saw during the 2009 economic downturn), people's opinions are sought and taken into consideration by leadership (anonymous employee surveys), opportunity for one to get stand by plane tickets (since FedEx is an airline), among many other reasons.
cons: Company grew very quickly and very big over the last 10-20 years and it's different businesess are not that well integrated (watch out that your job is not limited to a small silo.) Growth in US has been leveling off so there are not as many promotion opportunities as it used to be. There are some though and it's overall a fantastic company to work for.

pros: Become a strong individual.
cons: Bad upper management need to be more involved.

pros: good pay good benefits for job.
cons: long physically demanding hours in climate

review: I was a package handler and I loved it!
pros: I was a casual package handler and loved it! Casual handler was a no benefits position, but if you stayed around long enough then you could get a Permanent Part-Time position that would include benefits. It was a great part-time job and it even had benefits available for working just 17 hours. It was fast paced, but I worked closely with other employees and developed good relationships with many employees in a short amount of time. I would definetely recommend this job to anyone looking for a supplemental part-time job.
cons: Due to the nature of the work, all handlers were required to work strict schedules. There is almost no schedule flexability at all, unless you were a Permanent Part-Time and used Personal Time Off. Other than that, I loved everything else about the job!

review: 5 years in - Great Company, Antiquated Policies
pros:
- Low Stress Environment: nobody's competing or trying to steal your job
- Job Security: there is very little fear of being fired for being incompetent at a task. At worse, you fail and raise some gossip behind your back
- Work/Life Balance: depending on your team, sometimes you can go missing for days (unannounced) and nobody really bats an eye - benefit of the doubt, but don't push it
cons:
- Low Stress Environment: nobody wants to do any innovative or challenging work outside their job description
- Job Security: since no one thinks they can get fired, no one takes initiative on anything that doesn't come directly from their manager - and even then, challenging may ensue
- Pay Plateau: be wary and do the math first. Whatever salary you enter making will not change much over the course of time. Promotions are more time-based than merit, so it doesn't really matter if you do a great job or not...just do your time and you'll get there, 3% (yearly) or 7% (promotion) at a time. Until you hit your payband cap at least - then you're just stuck forever.

review: Good job if you have no asiprations other than a paycheck.  Those with ambition look elsewhere.
pros: Flexibility - Fedex is very casual and laid back.  Unless you work in dot-com or other critial business areas you'll work 40 hours or less a week.
cons: Politics, micromanagement, meetings -  it depends on which area you work but getting ahead at FedEx is about who you know and who you network with at FedEx.  The secret to getting ahead at FedEx is to make it your life, bleed orange and purple, be on your blackberry 24/7/365 to your mgrs.  Excessive reporting on your activities.  Each month I have 2 meetings with my director on project updates, monthly dashboard updates, weekly timekeeping and weekly project meetings.  Anything less and you'll be branded a "cowboy" or not a team player.  More time is spent on how you do things vs. getting the work done.

review: Enjoyed the people (co-workers and customers), the company did not involve the ops side of the business in decesions.
pros: Great benefits, however the benefits were not the same for FedEx Office as they were for the FedEx's parent company.  Training was good and on=going, both on=line and occasional classroom training.  Advancement opportunity was great, they truly promote from within.
cons: On the FedEx Office side, FedEx did not involve the opeartions side in any decesions they rolled out that could affect their customers or co=workers.  Unrealistic goals were set for stores to achieve in the area of sales, again this is where involvement would be helpful.  Store management would have been able to offer information that should have been considered when setting budgets for their areas (local economy, competition, etc.).  Too much change, SOP's would change weekly, I would describe it a the spagetti test.  They would roll out a new policy or process and not wait long enough to test the process before changing it again (throw spagetti at a wall and not wait long enough to see if it would stick).  They lost credability with co-workers and made it difficult to manage and hold co-workers accountable with the constant changes.

pros: They recognize you with gifts for years of service.
cons: No room for advancement. Pay is not good.

pros: You have a steady source of income.
cons: You work long hours with little recognition.

review: The worst place to work unless you like carrying others (Memphis employee reviews are happy as Springfield carries them)
pros: Always work to be done.
cons:
- Excessive overtime that is mandatory.
- Required to "assist" others to get their work done.  No self accountability, and this only applies to the favorites.
- Favoritism.
- Next to no room for advancement.
- Wages are about 20 years behind.  In no way competitive for the responsibility and knowledge required for the position.
- GM only supports the growth of people like her, and if you are any different she will ensure you do not advance and your get nickel and penny raises.  The worst in favoritism.  She fires people for not doing things that even she cannot handle in her position.
- New hires get hired on for more than tenored staff makes after 10+ years of service.
- The office is much like high school and has lots of cliques.  If you aren't "popular" people will treat you bad.
- Mistreatment by other employees will never be addressed by management. Despite all the politically correct information in the handbook, they will allow other employees to bully individuals.  
- Your family and personal life must come last.  Unless again you are part of the popular crowd, then you are allowed long lunches to go shopping.

review: FedEx:  High Employee Expectations Enhances Brand
pros: FedEx is a company that has high expectations for it's employees and is always striving for excellence.  This attitude is what enables the FedEx brand to be so well considered.  Salaries are fair and the benefits are terrific.  The fact that FedEx provides a pension for their employees demonstrates their commitment to their "People First" ideal.
cons: Too many performance metrics makes it almost impossible to get a perfect report card and can become distracting to performing the job at hand.  Lot's of time is involved outside of the office.  FedEx is not the place for a person who is only willing to work 40 hours a week.

review: Trustworthy company with good growth opportunities
pros: FedEx's current CEO is the original founder of the company with great dreams. This is good because the company has not lost track any time and has been very successful. The management has shown integrity and effectiveness in the past 35 years of history and is one of the virtual duopolies in the US. In the current  economic turmoil FedEx has shown tremendous strength and resorted to salary cuts and downsizing in a seemingly  fair,  controlled and minimal  way.  The company provides good opportunities for advancement and compensation and advancement are generally performance based. I have not heard of any  discrimination based on race, sexual orientation etc. in this company. In short FedEx is a reliable company with good growth opportunities.
cons: There is some red-tape and  it is probably because of the size of the company. The company is conservative and hence chances for innovation are not too many.

pros: The benefits are nice here.
cons: The people can be sometimes mean.

pros: Solid Fair Company.  Great branding and visualization.  It is truly wonderful to come to work where people care about one another and enjoy working together for a greater purpose, which is to service the world.  FedEx helps the Economy and we definitely do our share of supporting outside causes such as United Way.  It was absolutely amazing at how many were willing to volunteer their time and efforts this past Christmas Day and never complained about it.  We just knew it had to be done.  It made me proud that when companies are dying out there from the soft economy that our leader, Fred Smith, stood up for his company and said instead of downsizing and layoffs, we are going to take a pay decrease from my salary on down.  That shows someone who cares.
cons: It is so competitive that it is hard at times to move ahead professionally speaking.

review: Great work-life balance, Nice values, Nice people, Nice resources/technologies and a weak , redundant middle management
pros:
-FedEx has a mostly great , non-flighty attitude towards it's employees. It focuses on timeless values of "respect" and "building stability "  versus "use-and-throw" !!

- Great work/life balance 

- Good resources/advanced technologies /advanced training opportunites in Marketing for professional development.

- Good ethnic diversity !

- Internal promotion
cons:
- Weak, incompetent middle managers who were plain lucky to get promoted during the need time in early 2000.Not much leadership skills or intellectual abilities seen.

- Promotions can be based on a personal liking versus a collective / objective one.

- Rules, privileges ( such a remote working permisiion) changes from group-to-group ! Some are more equal than others.

review: A job to pay the bills
pros: It's a good, physical job that is rewarding when you step back and see how much you do in a day. Every day is different, with changing challenges and new experiences. The company always hires from within so if you're willing to work hard and climb the ladder this is a great opportunity.
cons: The hours will destroy your social life. Although it's normal for a salary position to work more then forty hours a week it's when the hours happen during the day that is the killer. My current position is from 1 P.M.-10 P.M. Mon-Fri so forget going out at night with spouse, family or friends during the week and doing all of your errands in the morning. The other option is from 10 P.M.-6 A.M. which may give you the better part of your evening back but it takes a certain type of person to do a job this physical on a third shift schedule.

review: Good company but the halo is questionable.
pros:
Integrity of executive leadership
People Service Profit culture and respect of persons
Some working flexibility
cons:
Very difficult to advance and grow, many people are frustrated. Structure internal interview process favors those who learn the process over merit and ability. Little incentive to move laterally results in in-breeding in many - not all - departments.
Push to broaden management span has decreased management opportunities.
Executive leadership has had a history of putting profit above people while stating the opposite. Promised bonus has not been paid at  100% for over ten years. No visibility into the bonus process despite the CFO's video communications, which only results in further questions. 
People Service Profit culture is lip service with many vps, directors, and managers.
Remote working opportunities have been restricted.
Many aspects of the culture and working environment are stuck in the 80s and 90s,
Nepotism - the chairman's son started at a hard-to-get principal position and is the fastest-rising executive  with apparently no competition for positions.

pros: Great people to work with!  Good work/life balance if you know how to manage your time.  Just do your work and you will ahve a place to work for a long time.
cons: Typical corporate jibberish.  What salesforce hears from upper managerment during the rah rah sessions (middle mgt excluded) and what middle mgt is told and does is usually quite different.  I was located in AZ and the closest HR rep is 1200+ at Corp.  That can make for some interesting situations and lack of HR support.  Most of us felt like we had no advocate.

pros: Perks are great. You get about 5 raises the first year. Very flexible schedule, you work Monday thru Friday but if you need a day off your manager has your back. Fun if youre with the right people. SUPER EAZY TO GET INTO THE JOB. We get free food all the time and t-shirts!
cons: If you do the math...the amount of hours + the amount of pay + plus the amount of physical labor you do = not worth it for me. I'm 5'2 and weigh a little of 100lbs. And I've been doing this job for the past 3 months, and I've done really good. Except for I'm broke and I can't wear shorts because I'm covered in bruises and people think I get abused at home. It's a decent in between jobs job. also, it might be easy to move up but you can't apply for another position until you've been there for at least 6 months. They make it out to be your fault if you get injured on the job but will throw a fit if you don't report it.

pros: Work load isn't much, great for student
cons: Pressure, lack of management

pros: 401k matching and affordable insurance.
cons: minimal advancement opportunities.  unorganized. unprofessional. no incentive to work to full potential.  insufficient training.

pros:
Great benefits and if you do your job (not even well) you can count on staying employed.  The salary is competitive and the company is good at what it does.

Many good managers - great work-life balance.  They really do care about their staff.
cons:
There are a lot of old timers (20+ yrs) that won't quit - no matter how many buy outs are offered.  This is a constant frustration since there is little focus put on getting ahead of the competition in the digital arena.  Many middle management are stone walls for progress and are overly concerned with (outdated) process adherence and internal metrics that only impact year end internal goals - not based on progress in the market.  There are some GREAT managers - but a bad managing director can and often will skunk up the teams beneath them.  

More meetings than are needed and far too many obstacles to innovation.

If you like a fast pace and modern tech - you need to look into the marketing team - the Services/TechConnect side will only frustrate you.

pros: Great Exposure to many Companies with instant credibility to get in and help them growth their business with logistics consulting.  Anyone who has the right attitude at this company will succeed.
cons: It is So Fun & Exciting  it is Hard to balance Work & Life at Home.

review: Undervalued, monotonous work with okay benefits
pros:
The training is nice, but depending on the department you are going to, could be completely useless.
Co-workers generally nice and helpful, though you may get in trouble for asking them questions on the floor, as management theory is that no one knows what they're doing.
3 weeks vacation, 10 sick and 6 floating holidays. When those benefits start depend on your hire month. You can go maybe 6 months without vacation, depending on your start date, but that is pretty normal.
cons:
Work is monotonous, as is most data entry, can't say it wasn't expected.
Stressful to be both efficient (lots of files processed) and accurate (zero mistakes, even human error typos count against you).
Little room for career advancement.
Monthly reviews are meant to be helpful but come across as either punishment or an excuse to pile on extra work if you perform well for no extra benefits.

pros: People based company.  Train well and let people make their own decisions and don't micromanage.  Excellent training and they ensure that you understand your responsibilities well.  Remove obstacles from employees so they are free and willing to go above and beyond for the customer
cons: Growing too quickly.  Acquired ground and companies split rather than remaining one solidified company.  It works well for specialization in certain areas, but leaves employees not having a well rounded understanding of everything the company has to offer the customer.

pros: You can make decent money but is it worth your sanity.
cons: The whole management is corrupt.

pros: Quite a diverse array of people from all backgrounds. Pretty flexible with people's schedules.
cons: There have been a few occasions where I was called to come in because a manager thought he was overwhelmed. By time I got there things were normal. Extremely poor judgement call on management's side. I've learned to avoid the phone now and I've lost confidence in the person as a leader. Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me. Work-life balance is fairly good except during "peak" times. Promotion is hardly based on merit. A lot of favoritism at the place I work at. For example, a lot of family members have become management in a blink of an eye.

pros: It is a good company with excellent benefits.
cons: I worked for five years and I had to quit when I had my twin babies since unfortunately the Human Resource Department did not want to give me a better option to stay with my babies for at least two more months after my FMLA expired even with a letter from the Doctor about the necessity of being more time taking care of the babies as they were still too little.  I was wrongfully treated by this HR manager when I tried to go and say goodbye to my co-workers and drop off my ID, like if I was leaving the company in bad terms. I feel a big dissatisfaction in the way the company let me leave and after five years of good work and sacrifice I was treated in a wrong way " like if instead of giving five good years of exceptional work and compromise with the company, I was stealing something or offend in any way to my employer ".

review: Being the best is hard work!
pros: FedEx is a great place to work! Everyone here works for a common goal "To make a customer experience outstanding" via the FedEx Purple Promise.  Also, there's so many opportunities to grow in the company. I've been employed here for 2 years and 11 months and have been promoted 3 times.  The opportunities are endless, you just have to put yourself out there and strive to be the best becasue you are representing the best.
cons: The only downside is that upper management is what I consider to be "old school". I think it's high time to let some of the younger professionals take a shot at making this great company even greater.  I feel that fresh ideas is what's needed to get through our current economic crisis.

pros: Very employee friendly. You will get to work with a very smart, highly efficient set of co-workers without a cut-throat environment.
cons: Since most people dont leave FedEx after joining, promotions become more difficult. Although the company has a policy for promoting from within, it is highly competitive and almost like an internal job application rather than an automatic promotion based on superior performance. Due to this, your "interviewing skills" and ability to "sell yourself" become as important, if not more, than the job skills necessary to suceed in the new position. Not a bad thing necessarily.

review: Work is fast paced, managers are cool, little hours, good pay.
pros:
Benefits, Fed Ex pays at most a weeks vacation. If you are a student you have the opportunity to apply for tuition reimbursement, but you must be passing classes. 
Managers are understanding and are cool if you ask for a day off, like most jobs though you can't be missing too much days.
cons: Work is fast paced, you have constant work. The part time job of 24 hours weekly feels like a full time job at times because of the hard labor. If you go for a quick break to the restroom the boxes pile up and you have to work even faster to catch up.

pros: Something is always screwed up, so even part-timers can usually get all the hours they want. If you like to keep moving all day this job is for you. The medical benefits are crap now, but that's not peculiar to FedEx. Even part-time hires immediately get the same medical as everyone else. No dangling carrot mirages, you get hired, you've got medical. 2 weeks vacation, 3 after 5 years, 4 at 10 years, 5 at 20.  You CAN start at the bottom and work your way up to work group manager, senior manager, regional director, division vice president. Virtually all middle management is hired from within.
cons: Management varies WILDLY. It's a crap shoot if you have a good manager or a nut job.  If you get injured on the job they will NOT have your back.  If you like Christmas, forget about being a courier, for ANY company.

pros: Independent, hands-on shifts make time fly. (Pickup route) The majority of your time is spent running your route in your truck, interacting with consistent regulars and daily on-calls.
cons: You have the same window of time to complete all stops in your area assigned to you that day. That means that, while sometimes you will have plenty of time to complete a few stops, other times you will have too many to keep up with. If you don't manage to complete all your assigned stops on time, you are penalized.

pros: Very dynamic company to work for while learning and growing everyday.  Professional environment,  team work but also independently responsible for lots of responsibilities.  Diverse company with lots of growth potential.
cons: Interview process was a little difficult but I guess that's to weed out the good from the bad.  Communication with boss a little challenging often times because they're extremely busy.  Fast pace  environment (which can also be a good thing) ... lots of processes change daily so it can be difficult to grasp onto methods with them constantly becoming new.  Not much bad about this company though.  All cons can be easily perceived as pros!

pros: Leader in the industry.  Job security.  good pay.  The company is one of the few that still has substantial benefits including a defined benefit pension still available.  There is also an opportunity to work in all states and in many countries around the world ..... The company is expanding in many areas of the world especially China.   Many opportunities exist in the southeast asian and asian areas of operations.  Promotions to high levels are possible in these areas
cons: Lack of support for people.  YOu are a "number".  If it hurts you for the company to save a penny, they still will.

review: I am lucky to be working for a company like FedEx
pros:
The Culture,  - People, Service Profit
I started working for Fedex while in college, I received full benefits working part time, and was re-cruited into the sales force.  That was about 8 years ago, I have grown both personally and professionaly because of the wonderful collegues and leadership and I feel very lucky.  Even during hard economic times, FedEx still has a no lay off policy, and really focus on the best for there employees and our customers. I am very proud to tell people where I work.
cons: Pay is not as competitive in other sales positions, other collegues have been able to move on to other sales positions within the transportation industry for much more money, although  things are always changing at FedEx, I feel the lifestyle of working for such a company out wieghts the extra money.

review: Great company with a "please all" attitude!
pros: Work life balance, reasonable salary and good benefits. Depending on where you work your job could be challenging and rewarding too. Never a boring moment.
cons:
Extremely limited opportunities for career advancement and promotions. They hire the best in the world and then let them languish at the same position for years without any hope of a promotion.  The promotion policy is vague and undefined...usually depends on who you know and who knows you. Merit is not always the criteria.

The company's attitude of trying to please everybody promotes mediocrity and frustrates and demotivates high performers.

pros: People, Service, Profit philosophy outstanding concept other companies should adopt; FedEx invests in all employees' education and training with lots of growth opportunity when starting out in the work force. Fantastic experience and great skill builder, recommend this exposure as a base to anyone's career. Reward and recognition also shared across all employee levels.
cons: Difficult to get into upper management, people hold onto jobs for long time at headquarters in Memphis, TN because there are only a few companies in town that are comparable to FedEx.
job title: Senior Program Manager/Systems Architect/Quality Assurance Analyst

pros: Good insurance packages, a steady source of income. Lay-off is a bad word over here. It is also a good place to start your customs brokerage career and a great learning platform.
cons: You will need personal motivation to not get stuck in the veneer of comfort this place will create. And that is all it is, a veneer. The steady paycheck and benefits can lull you into not pushing yourself towards advancing your career and it appears to be designed to do just that

pros: FedEx Services believes in what we call the Purple Promise.... People Service Profit... All work had in glove to make a great company a great place to work. FedEx is intentional in making sure that employees become an integral part of this culture by periodically hosting meetings for not just managers, but for the vast majority of employees to attend, even when it means flying them across the country. They put their money where their mouth is. Many companies talk about similar ideas and it pretty much dies there. FedEx Services puts their beliefs into practice.
