pros: Those who say "no challenge"  you're in the wrong business. Good pay, benefits, camaraderie, personal challenge!
cons: Can be long hrs, especially holidays, nature of the business!

pros: Great pay and benefits. Employees there are all very nice. Good working and communication environment. Good work and life balances.
cons: Location is not good.FedEx is the only large company there. And memphis is a really boring and unsafe city. There is not much to do after work.

pros: alot of great people to work with and if you leave on good terms you can always come back It is a good job with good benefits
cons: During peak season be prepared to work your tail off it is a good company and has a lot of good benefits

pros: It's hard work but if u stick to it it pays off
cons:
Very demanding 
Hot
Better ways to get in out 
Need two people to a truck when loading or at least someone to help handle the packages off when it's an heavy flow

pros:
Part time hours are great
will keep you in shape
they start out with good pay and benefits
cons:
I think its a good part time job than a full time job.
you cant take off during the month of december
If you have a family it can be tough getting days off

pros: Financially stable, globally recognized company with an array of reliable transportation services available to clients. There is not a lot of micro-management in general, but there are some exceptions.
cons: A lot of selling time is corrupted by an abundance of reporting and continually changing technology and systems.

review: great place to make part time cash.
pros: mon- fridays, weekly pay, paid holiday, vacation, medical , dental, vision. four hour work day. it was great.
cons: Most of the people, don't carry their work load.

review: Part Time pay with Full Time expectations.
pros: The possibility of moving into other positions
cons: The unrealistic expectations for $200.00

pros: Good benefits and busy atmosphere, independent work which provides great individual accountability. Great flexibility working PT as a FO courier while studying as well too.
cons: turnover rate because of pay or promotion.

pros: FedEx works well with its employees in relation to furthering education and this is something I appreciate in this season of my life.
cons: This is a physically demanding job.  At times I like the work out of it, yet in other moments my body just aches.

pros: good company, great benefits, knowledgeable sr mgmt
cons: very structured, hard to work "quickly" through organization,  only known in your area and not known outside your department so dont know about other opportunities

pros: As long as you do what is asked, little chance of being let go. Good benefits after min. time employeed is achieved.
cons: No set schedule, hard to adjust to the hours.

review: So far my experience has been an education into the real operations of a major distributor.
pros: A very lean and efficient company with an outstanding supply chain system.
cons: Sometimes you have to wear a few different hats to get the job done right.

review: I enjoyed working at FedEx because it was fast paced, enjoying driving and meeting new people.
pros: I enjoyed driving, delivering packages, meeting new people, the pay and the work ethics.
cons: Loading the truck in a manner that is easily accessible for the different deliveries.

review: If you're a courier...get ready to eat hours
pros: Different couriers all working together to get the work done.
cons: Read "Independent Contractor (Current Employee) Florence, KY". Very helpful insight as to the roots of the problem at FedEx - they have ******completely**** you could say "washed their hands clean" of driving responsibility by pushing everything onto contractors...but then stopped compensating them for everything. Belts have been tightened at every step. You're not compensated for your time AT ALL, most every location pays couriers PER DAY, so if you're out 15 hours, your pay is god-awful and possibly below min. wage depending on where you live.

review: If you are willing to work hard, they are willing to promote
pros: School reimbursement, 401K match & good medical. Good training.
cons: You can get stuck ... some managers / directors will prevent your advancement. Evaluations are too cumbersome with too many levels.

review: This is my first time applying to this company
pros: The reason I want to work for FedEx is that FedEx is a world wide company that I heard so much good stuff about it
cons: I have no cons I hope this will be my first time working for this company

pros: Family type of environment. Lots of opportunities for overtime, especially during the holiday season. You can receive benefits while part time.
cons: Extremely hard on the body. It's possible and likely to sustain minor to major injuries from the repetitive  motions and lots of times heavy lifting or pushing.

review: It is a very satisfying and challenging experience.
pros: There are a lot of pros. Very conducive learning environment. Employees are respected and valued for the work they do.
cons: The career path is not very clearly delineated. The pre-existing structures can sometimes inhibit growth. Tendency to get into a comfort zone.

pros: People were always ready to help. Room for vertical and horizontal movement. Great work life balance. Everyone was friendly around the office.
cons: Cubicles. Everyone worked in cubicles. Even though the campus was beautiful (courtyards, paths, lake), the actual working areas was full of cubes and artificial light.

pros: great benefits, hard work rewarded, flexible and relaxed atmosphere. Opportunities are there if you put in the dedication. Always improving.
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of accountability, especially when it comes to poor performance.

pros:
Tools, technology and operational programs are the engine of the entire operation system .
Hours and workers are always available .
Safety environment .
cons: Fedex is a fast paced industry in which some times decision are productive but no quite efficient .

pros:
benefits for part-time were good.  When you were on the road you are pretty much left alone.
management does recognize good work and will document such.
cons:
stressful to meet time deadlines when you can only drive so fast.
on days when there were less stops the avg stops per hour will obviously correlate to that.  so mgmt will tell you that you need to improve on that.  no way to do that unless there are more stops which you cannot have control of that.  
Some managers better than others.

pros: Enjoy working with people making sure the  customer co.email first
cons: opportunity for growth within the company to expand my ability to learn more for possible management position of each day

pros:
Up on your feet almost all the time and always lifting heavy packages giving you a work out. 
As long as you are a hard worker managers are nice people.
Good benefits.
cons: The hours don't pick up until peek season which is November - January.

review: This is the Pathfinder position, which doesn't require a degree in a related field.
pros: Friendly community. Everyone is helpful.
cons: The offer for this position was in email format, so no real room for haggling the starting pay. Still better than anything entry-level around here.

pros: Health benefits, do your job and manager is great
cons: working overnight can hurt your work / life balance

pros: FedEx is a fast paced environment and there is always something new to learn.  Pay is good on years where the bonus is good, but the bonus isn't guaranteed even if you meet all your yearly goals for your particular building.
cons: Annoying internal audit procedures that cost more time than the actual operations.  Managers are expected to be on call 24/7 and working on vacation is encouraged.  In the northeast most higher ups are bullies who will yell at you constantly and tell you to fix things without guidance on how to do so.  You are expected to learn and implement everything yourself.

review: Corporations with "staying power" evolve with the times.
pros: Benefits are the best reason.  Salary is adequate as well.
cons: Internal politics are a bit of a challenge, especially when there is a major "changing of the guard" at the top

pros: Job until you find a better one.
cons: Went out of their way to remove employees who had full term benefits,pensions,sick pay, in order to bring in outsiders at a lessor pay and benefits. This is a normal tactic or practice at this company, and to harrass and follow employees to further terrorize them....Go to U.P.S and save yourself the years of wasted time and aggravation....

pros: Fedex pays tuition assistance of up to three thousand dollars a year.  They also provide basic benefits despite being only part time.
cons: The biggest draw back is starting at 4 am.  Work outside in the cold.  Amount of hours worked varies greatly per week.

pros: Flexible schedules depending on your manager. Generally good professional opportunities and work life balance. Company is people focused, even though like all companies compensation isn't keeping up with inflation and Benefit cost increases.
cons: Lack of empowerment of front line management and employees in the professional environment

pros: Rewarding benefits by far; enjoy the work and most of the co-workers.
cons: Environmental conditions can be taxing, given the weather and its fluctuations.

pros: Good company culture overall. Good work/life balance. Good benefits
cons: There are some people get on fast track due to personal relationship with management, not because of their ability.

pros: FedEx provides good benefits and job security. Most employees are dedicated and hard workers. Average opportunities for advancement.
cons: Company is very rigid and there is not a lot of opportunity to effect change. Management doesn't respond to employee input enough.

pros: FedEx is a great company to work for. FedEx has has great benefit package and vanguard retirement system.
cons: The only downside I think is that you would be working in various weather conditions outside.

pros: The pay and benefits are a plus.
cons: Its a dangerous work place and loses a lot of new hires.

pros: Great Company, with good benefits and opportunities to move up. The nice thing about FedEx is the possibility of working pretty much anywhere on the planet.
cons: They Changed the commission structure a few years ago. It isn't as lucrative as it once was for a sales person.

pros:
The pay was good and the ambiance is very nice.
The people there are working there for years so it feels very stable and home-like.
cons: The pay is not that great and they dont invest in there employees to develop. The management is old and very slow.

pros: I make $17.10 an hour & I have good insurance benefits.
cons: They don't let you take off days of vacation you have up available sometimes & they don't go by seniority.

pros: Great benefits, clean environment, overtime great. Management does a well job with getting coaching and development done.
cons: Have not ran into any cons yet. I have been with the company  for a short period of time. So that this time I have  no cons.

pros: Pay is good; colleagues are friendly and motivated; management is generally flexible and humane; benefits are good; nature of work can be stimulating and challenging.
cons: Big, big company brings big bureaucracy; getting things done can take a long time.

pros: Great experience, top notch company that will only progress in the digital age.
cons: None that I can think of. I worked here many years ago.

pros: Benefits, Opportunities are pretty good, help with schooling. raises are consistent. Overall great place to start a career.
cons: Hardly any full-time positions, some people can't deal with the conditions that come with the job.

pros: No red tape, great management, I felt straight at home during this long career at FedEx
cons: Too much red tape, the management is not great, and made me feel uneasy at times

pros: Great People Service Profit (PSP) culture and tons of career opportunity. Very customer driven and people-oriented. Absolutely love the company.
cons: Due to the multiple operation companies, there are some overlap in job functions which adds much communication cost and interest conflict.

pros: Worklife balance, low cost of living in memphis, Fortune 500 company, one of the best brands, most admired companies in the world. You are not expected to put in more than 40 hours of work each week and do get fabulous discounts with retailers/restaurants in memphis
cons: If you are looking for career path and career growth, management typically looks down on people with initiative and aggressive career goals. They mostly want followers and people who follow them blindly without asking any questions.. Middle management has limited leadership capabilities and minimal business skills.

review: FEDEX IS CHANGING! IT IS THE COMPANY OF YESTERDAY! THE ORGANIZATION NO LONGER VALUES THEIR EMPLOYEES
pros:
FedEx was a great place to work.  When I came to work for this company, I truly believed that it was an organization that cared about their employees.  I thought it was a company where I could advance, grow and use the full range of my educational abillities.  Unfortunately, after working for the company for almost 5 years,  I have discovered that things are changing greatly at FedEx.   FedEx is not a company that cares about their employees.  I understand that the economic conditions are impacting this organization. However, I was very disappointed when the news revealed that I would be receiving a pay deduction before I was aware. To make matters worse, I opened an e-mail to read about the changes that would be effective immediately. I had to call my manager for clarification. This information was not proactively provided to me.  What a disappointment? Did the company care about me? I wanted notification so that I could make the necessary adjustments and pay. To add insult to injury, the press release said that the pay deduction would be permenant and I would not receive a merit increase in 2009.  I would be a little more accepting if the company was committed to bringing me back up to the my current salary level after the economic situation improves. There was no commitment.  Health insurance costs continue to increase as well.

I cannot think of a good reason to work for FedEx, now.
cons: If you are working as a Field Account Executive, you are in a deadend career. There are very few promotion opportunities until you know someone or play the "kiss your- you know what" game. Educations, sales success - it does not really matter. Also, the requirements of even advancing to the next grade level is nearly impossible.

pros: easy to get hired.  They provide pay to get your commercial driver's license (CDLs).  Free uniforms.  Recognizeble employer that provides good resume experience.  Get exercise while working.
cons: little control over number of hours you're working.  Frequently log 50+ hours.  Blue collar mentality.  Sometimes you feel under-appreciated.

pros: Great Workout, Good managers, good pay for no higher education, Tuition Assistance!
cons: Hard Work, If you not really to bust your ass, being a FedEx Package Handler is not meant for you.

review: Great company, managers can make or break career
pros: Nationally recognized name, known product.
cons: Some managers want you to pull blood from a rock. Culture of the business allows customers to switch to a competitor at anytime. No one knows exactly how compensation works. You could have a great quarter or a bad one...it all depends on how your goals are set and the "behind-the-scenes" calculations that go on. Work/life: not out of the ordinary to do admin work until 9-10pm. Almost expected.

pros: FedEx is a great company to work for and really balances the needs of the employees with a strong desire to serve our customers while also taking care of the shareholders.
cons: There are no cons that should keep someone from considering a career with FedEx.

pros: Nice good people working there. Your always kept busy, which is nice. You open to learn more of each dept. They are always open for any suggestion to improve or help the work situation.
cons: Since they are under Homeland Security Ordinance they have no vending machines.

review: Lots of opportunities and LOTS of challenges
pros: growing for the last few years which leeds to advancment opprtunities
cons: This may be part of FedEx but they operate more like a startup.

pros: Great benefits even for part time including but not limited to; health insurance and help with college tuition, and 401k benefits.
cons: No opportunity for full time unless a manager, or you do two part time jobs at the location as it is a small facility.

pros: A typical US company, relax environment. But for interns, there were deadlines to present your outputs. A little bit stress when being an intern.
cons: Slow cycle of feedback and must struggle to get info by yourself. No moves no gains.

pros: Beats being homeless,good pay,job security.
cons: Retirement just cash pension, Health benefits inadequate,Retiree healthcare $1,000 per mon. work rules change daily, things are so bad we are in the middle of an organizing drive to have the Teamsters represent us in Aircraft Maint. We WILL get a CONTRACT.This Co. has gone from being A place that once held strong to the PSP philosophy(people,service,profit),now its all about the profit and keeping Wallstreet happy.

pros: Health benefits, pay for the location, work/life balance, treatment of employees
cons: Tougher (but not impossible) to move around the company geographically for non-operational / non-sales management and above positions.  Many/most are in Memphis.

pros:
People First Culture
Customer Experience Driven Management
Brand stregth
Superior service quality with high standards
Promotes team work and innovation
cons: Too political at times, and cycle time for new service introduction is length

review: Fast paced ,fun place to work, good training program
pros: Great people, Good pay, fast pace makes time go fast
cons: Deadlines are tough to meet during peak times, work comes in bursts

pros: Benefits, co-workers, 401k and pension.
cons: There is no work, life, balance. You need to work 10 hour sales days and do your admin work after that so its more of a 12 hour day. Very little corporate support. They give you all kinds of initiatives but very little support for it. Don't ever work in the BSF position.

pros: The people you'd work with a world-class professionals. FedEx does make the world a better place by providing access for everyone. The company's culture focuses on people and starts with Fred Smith and the executive team.
cons: Speed of change can be improved

review: Overall,  a great company to work for!
pros: Opportunities for advancement,  competitive salary, great training program.
cons: Company likes to make a lot of changes!, Heavy responsibilities may require long hours, stressful environment.

pros: Great core culture and values.  Good work life balance.  Strong benefits package including a portable pension.
cons: Compensation is fair.  Advancement opportunities are very limited outside of Memphis, TN

pros: Good Technologies to work with.  Lots of freedom to do your job.
cons: Lower than avg salaries.  Lots of silos.

pros:
Great health benefits for part time work AFTER first 90 days employment.
Extra fringe benefits such as cell phone discounts, rental cars, vacation packages, travel discounts.
Paid vacations accrued by hours worked.
cons: Extremely time oriented, 1 second late to work is a LATE.

pros: Your somewhat like your own boss on the road as long as you deliver the packages your in very good standing.
cons: Every day is unpredictable not really just knowing how many stops you might have.

pros: Fedex provides great compensation for employees with good starting pay and fast pay increase, after a year part-time employees get great benefits.
cons: I didn't see any downside to working at Fedex unless working very early in the morning is not a good fit for you.

review: Good job to start out with
pros: FedEx is a larger organization with chance to move all around the globe.
cons: FedEx makes billion of dollars but because it is so big the profit sharing stinks.

pros: Company benefits, consistent hours if you're willing to put in the work
cons: It's HOT, and it takes a toll on your body.

pros: You learn how the packages travel from one city to another.every body work together.
cons: by me working in the airport when we have down time we have to go to adiffrent departmen and help out until the aircraft come in.

review: Get out while you still can...
pros: EASY work...does not require a lot of brain power.  The hardest park about the job is just getting the motivation to come in on a daily basis and dealing with bad weather.
cons: Working with a bunch of people that are as lazy as I've ever seen and a company that expects you to keep learning additional skills and processes without any kind of reward or pay raise.  If you like working for a company that won't give you a raise for years at a time and new hires that make within $1.00/hr of employees that have been with the company for a decade, than FedEx is your company.

pros: Great hours and great pay, lots of opportunity for growth! Make sure to work hard, and stick to it!
cons: Morning shift takes a while to get used to the hours, but once you get used to it, its not so bad.

pros: Great people, good management, excellent service. Good work/life balance.

Also in their zealousness to encourage diversity, they discard and disregard people who have been working with them for years, just because their fault is they belong to the "Majority" so there is a culture of rewarding someone from a different background even though that person is a non-performing member.

pros: Good Work life balance, family oriented, great compensation and benefits, quality driven management, people first culture, growth opportunities across different career fields, good training,

pros: Secure working environment.  Excellent Service offering to the customers .

review: Profitable Organization - Culture Suffers from Over OutSourcing.
pros:

Challenging Work - Lots to do in the quest for simplification
Diverse Organization

People - Service - Profit philosophy?  When you have to teach people how to act something is missing.
No work life balance

pros: Love the job. Amazing Company. Work Life Balance. THEY LISTEN and TAKE PRIDE in their employees. Could not see myself elsewhere. Countless of career opportunities.

review: You just dont hear the negative, that doesnt mean it's that great of a place - good spin doctors at FedEx.
pros:
Fiscally aware and will enforce pay cuts vs. laying off.
Benefits are decent.
cons:
Political.  Not much standardization for the sales force i.e., a type of sink or swim environment with tools flying at us that are not properly tested before we get them.  These take up time we dont have but are required to use, only to have the next new thing be dumped on us a few weeks later.  It is like a contest to see who can make a name for themselves by coming up with a new technique and after that we have to work out the bugs.  By that time, another tool or training will be required.      We supposedly are given warm leads, but approx 40% of the spreadsheet are companies out of business, havent shipped in over 10 years, etc.  To close the sale we have to use a process, which means if a customer wants to ship with us the same day we call, we cannot close it unless we have a minimum of 3 calls.  AND we have to move the sale through a "certainty' rating, which means  we have to log the close as 25% sure, then 50% sure, then 75%, 90% then close it.   Many dont do it this way and just make sure they have the minimum 3 calls.  No one seems to believe that an inside sasales professional can know if the customer is wanting to ship in one or 2 calls.  Also, we now have a phone system that allows management to listen to our calls so there is the Big Brother aspect.  

Managers play favorites and there is no recourse to this as the manager network is tight.  I.e., it would do no good to report one as blatantly applying the rules according to their personal preferences vs. what is fair and equitable.  

The sales job requires a minutia of extraneous tasks in additional to actual selling.  The systems we have are not user friendly and it requires using 4-5 places to find all the information necessary to track our calls, pull up information about the customer and track the customer's shipping for closes.  There is a lag time to seeing how a customer is shipping, we have to wait 1-2 days to get pricing approved for them, etc.  And after we bring on an account and grow it, we then have to give it to the field sales reps who usually have not done a single thing to work the account.  Any objections will be answered with:  "It's the right thing for the customer."   Everyone in sales knows this is an untruth.   The other thing about field sales is FedEx seems to have a preference for hiring outside for field and had no problem hiring 70 layed off DHL reps which took promotional opportunities away from internal employees.    Speaking of promotional opportunities, 
promotional opportunities are largely dependent on the relationship with your manager.  So know what to kiss and when.

review: Solid company, for a middle of the road job.
pros: Easy to move around to different positions.  A job you don't have to worry about losing.  Most people have been around for a long time.  Management is usually hired from within.
cons: Difficult to get pay raises or any significant salary bumps.  Not a big push to excel.  Some people have been there for long time and stopped doing work a long time ago.

review: Great experience and place to work!
pros: FedEx truly cares about each employee and they understand that taking care of the workers will lead to the best service in the industry.
cons: Difficult to move up the ladder if you are not based in Memphis.

review: Great Values. Great Company. Great opportunity for a long-term career in any field.

cons: Many hours dedicated to administrative work.

pros:

review: I have over 13year's of experience In the customer service.
pros: I communicate well others and I enjoy makingbthe atmosphere welcoming.
cons: It's hard learning to adjust to changes but am Excited to see what I can Conquer.

pros: Lots of Manual Labor, basically a gym you get paid to go to. The people there are really nice, once you get to know them.

pros: FedEx is world renewed courier company with all the policy and procedures set up, methods are proven to follow, easy to adjust with stable job without worrying loss of job
cons: Less growth in the career and nothing much to be creative

pros: I loved my job, I loved working on my own and at times things were real good.  I liked the independent working. A new terminal was being built and I was excited about what would be coming soon. Depending on who you work for you could have a good experience.  I would go back to work for my current contractor if I could.
cons: Well it got to be that my route became so busy that I was working 12 hour days most of the time but only being paid for 8. At times I wasn't even making minimum wage due to the hours I was working. I probably didn't deliver 5 packages in my 4 years of service due to weather and I never called in sick once.  I did complain because there was a discrimination of whites at our FedEx and the handlers would come in late and then sit around and talk.  I was asked many times during holidays to clock out during delivery so I didn't go over federal guidelines for drive time. I also didn't get paid all the time from my first route contractor. I always did as I was told.  Then just two weeks ago I was pulled for a random drug test and I failed for marijuana.  I do not see how I could of failed, I have been around it but I am not a smoker.  I was told too bad, instantly fired by FedEx not my contractor boss.  I was then blacklisted from FedEx forever.  My heart was tore out. I worked my butt off for FedEx even though I was really not working for them but for a contractor without benefits, holiday pay or vacation time.  All this and I am still upset about not working at FedEx, hence still the #3 rating.

pros: Working from home.  Decent salary and benefits.
cons: More reporting than selling.  Can be micro-managed depending on who your manager and director are.

pros: Strategic vision from executive management with a commitment to continue to define, expand and secure FedEx's place as the industry leader.
cons: Sometimes "Silo" thinking and operating from the various operating companies hampers development and creativity. Politically and socially conservative - a very Republican-leaning company.

pros: You will never need to go to the gym again. Very physically demanding work, with decent pay. Hours are pretty flexible for the different sorts (Consisting of 3 to 4 hour shifts, or 7 to 8 for a double shift) taking place throughout the day. Most of the other workers who are tenured tend to treat you well and help where they can, surely so they can make some friends and help avoid turnover. Staff is generally kind and cares about you getting hurt, whether it be for company protection or your own well being- that can be a hit or miss depending on the manager/supervisor. Advancement is possible, although politics probably play into that for some people. Not all though.
cons: Sometimes, it seems they value quantity far more than quality. When we load trailers we sometimes get overloaded and you can easily get written up for not meeting their goals for the day. Normally, hitting the goal is handling and scanning 1 box every 7 seconds. This may not seem hard, but when the boxes coming down the chutes jam, you have to walk to the jam, break it, and hope that boxes don't spread all throughout the truck trailer. Sometimes labels are smeared and don't scan properly or at all. Little to no help most of the time, making the 1 box every 7 seconds hard at times. Management can sometimes treat you like a number, which working at a factory-like facility where you are easily replaced... Maybe that's not a con but more a norm sadly. Prepare to feel pain, whether it cuts, bruises or knots from where boxes ranging from 5 lbs. to 150 lbs. attack you.

pros: FedEx has good benefits and is diverse - at least in some larger markets.  There is a lot of opportunity for training and continuing your education, etc.

review: Working in Field Sales at FedEx

pros: The fact that you start off at 10.80/hr is a huge plus and for the first 3 months you get a raise.

pros: It‚Äôs very difficult to review FedEx and no one opinion can be generalized to reflect how this company works.  Being a large company it in a way works like the world itself.  There are some good parts that make you proud and there are some parts that will totally annoy and drive you out of the company.  So opinions will largely depend on which part do you face the most.  On overall level and it‚Äôs a well respected company led by a visionary. It‚Äôs in a good position in the industry as there are high barriers to entry especially on the Express and Ground business.   FedEx being in logistic domain is operationally driven company and luckily the management and systems are very strong where they should be.  If you work in the operation area this is a best place to work as company‚Äôs focus as well as all the services including IT are dominant in this area. However, if you work in shared services like Marketing or Sales this may seem like a terrible place as everything seems inferior in this area, management, systems.  FedEx is well known for path breaking advances in IT, but if you are in Services area, the IT support is abysmal.
cons:
Experience and opinion of FedEx are also largely shaped by individuals and their career aspirations.  For many folks, working in a stable company and living in an inexpensive place is more important and this place is ideal for them.  But if you are advanced degree holder looking for a good career growth this is not the place for you.  Career growth and  promotions especially in the management depend upon open position.  For every promotion you will have to apply for the position and compete with many individuals.  So even if you perform at the highest level there is no guarantee that you will get promoted as there may not be open positions and even if there is one, 20-30 people may be vying for the same job.  Many times the individual is chosen before all the interviews take place and then many people interview just so that hiring manager can complete the formality. 
This also leads a good point, being a large company the experience of FedEx largely depends on the Vice Presidents of the area.  If you are stuck in a group with ineffective or politically motivated VP, then you are out of luck.  I know of a VP who used to promote all his friends or well wishers or other reasons which are more speculations that known facts so not worth mentioning.  Most of his promotion decisions bombed but it still goes on.  He used to conduct interview even for regular promotions with no additional responsibility and give job to someone he likes and tell others that they didn‚Äôt interview well.   At the same time I also know of VPs who always strived to do what is right.

pros: Great benefits, paid days off, paid holidays, paid vacation. Reimbursement for any work related tools (ex. boots). Always a great workout and great atmosphere.
cons: Adjust to working nights. Hours are limited. Some people may find it too labor intense.

review: Great foundation for the transportation industry
pros: Benefits, Money, and Business Perks
cons: constantly working while at home

review: I enjoyed my 20 years at FedEx, the best service in the industry, without question.
pros: The salaries and benefits are adequate and job security is a given as long as you meet performance and productivity expectations, as well as not violating the Acceptable Contact Policies. In sales/sales management you get to work with various different companies/industries in different locations around the world. Also, the ability to be friends and work with mentors who are truly experts in their respective fields.
cons: Compensation, you will be provided a fair wage, however you will never get wealthy, yet upper level management makes a tremendous amount of money when compared to front line management. Major compensation issues in regard to being equally fair accross the board. The culture has changed, before the "merger" with RPS, the company truly put the employees first and followed the policy  of treat your employees well, and in turn your employees will provide the best possible service to our customers, and therefore profitability will follow. The policy worked for years but when the merger happened the employees were no longer treated with respect and were treated as if they were a liability that could be replaced on a whim. Also management by intimidation has become the culture of the day, with the new performance review system and the sales professionals and sales manager no longer have the empowerment to make decisions in which they could have made prior to 1999, and no longer able to run their perticular district or region as they wanted to. In the beginning the mantra was to run each territory/district/ region as it was the sales persons personal business, that is no longer an option.

review: Not as good of a company as everyone may think.
pros: Opportunity to learn a lot about printing and shipping.
cons: Promotions(they rarely promote within the company, if you are lucky enough to do so, it takes a loooong time, and barely a raise), raises suck, no company perks besides 75% off Express shipments, if you are "full time" you will be given about 30 hours(don't expect 40), the training SUCKS terribly...be prepared to learn EVERYTHING on your own as it happens.

pros: good work life balance, people first. i actually never saw any argues.and fights. people are so.nice to each other
cons:
lack of growth oppotunity
MEMPHIS is not a.good place to live.

pros: I like my job and try as much as possible to adavnce.  I am the spotter but what is that really saying? I learn how to do the job.  I can scan trucks, split 100,200 & 300 belts.  I finally got Insurance.  This is the first time that I wanted to work for somebody else in about 20 years.  I like the shift that I work.  It enable be to do construction work in the daytime.  I am very use to working hard and I know how to make my job work smoother.  I am a problem solver.  I apply my work ethics to Fedex and share what ever I can with who is willing to listen.  I hope one day to be come a manager
cons:
One of the mangers is a slave driver. He brings his personal problems to work with him.  Then he unloads it on the crew members.  Don't get him cross on that day when he comes in,in a bad mood.  That was yesterday.  Don't really know what I did.  He is like a hound dog just got a peice of your clothes given to him.  And everybody knows that he is out to get you.  
There are only three white people working on our shift.  It is very hard work.

Management good/bad, the good try to help where they can.  The bad are lazy and loud, sometimes at the same time. Avoid the midnight shift at all costs.

pros: Pay, vacation time and benefits are good for an unskilled worker like me.
cons: Fedex is currently in stupid/confused mode. They are buying up other transportation companies while taking their focus off the part of the company that started the whole show. Express volumes are way down due to sales shifting pkgs to Fedex Ground. They are mothballing aircraft and keeping vehicles well passed their service life. I would love to show pictures of the rusted piece of crap truck we just got rid. I'm sure investors would be interested in knowing what's really going on at Fedex. They take vehicles from station that some coffee dog in Memphis says the station doesn't need even though he/she doesn't have a friggin clue what the stations vehicle needs are. They put 2 wheel drive vehicles in parts of the country that need 4 wheel drive. Having 4 wheel drive vehicles is what separates us from the competition but upper management is too stupid to figure it out. The give us a raise and then raise our rates. They have a spending freeze so it's hard to get new uniforms. I've had the same shirts for a decade. If you are young and a hard worker and don't mind being stressed all the time Fedex is for you. You will learn to hate driving. I mean despise driving. Remember those weekend drives you took with your significant other? Say goodbye to them. You will not want to leave your home your days off. Christmas? Don't even get me started. You will come to hate your favorite holiday and will only put up with it for the sake of your kids. 20 years of my life wasted but they paid for my kids and my wife was able to be a stay home mom. So, it is what it is. Most of the employees I work with are smokers and alcoholics.

My manager is one of the worst managers I've we worked with. My schedule is constantly being tossed around without consideration of my personal life. This is one of the worst companies to work for. They do not practice what they preach in their mission statement.

The people seem like they are stuck and hopeless because this job is their only option. The job is very sedentary and could be boring after a while because it is glorified data entry.

pros: Hours are great-Work Tuesday-Saturday-Pay is good for part-time

pros:
Job Title sounds like an important job, and that may just help you get a real important job at a different company.
A lot of overtime available...so far. (They have been hiring many people so they won't have to pay overtime).  If you get $14/hr and you work 4 hours overtime everyday for a year, you can make 50k. Might be worth it for some people, definitely not for everyone.
cons:
It's basically a data entry job, don't let the title fool you. The pay is low, not a job for college graduates.   There are around 30 other people doing the same thing as you so seniority is going to play a big role in promotions.  They start you at around $14 or $15 per hour.  And you get like 2% raise each year, so you do the math. You will have to put in 4+ years just to get $1 raise.  There are other reviews here that proves it could be worse than the example i gave you.  At these kind of pay, a single person cannot survive since rent alone is around $1,000 + utilities for a studio.  This job is for kids living with parents or for people with a significant other that is making the big money.  How does the company get away with paying so low? 
They hire minorities(some can't even speak proper English) who would otherwise have a hard time finding a job.  If you are a white person, don't bother applying to Sr. Entry coordinator positions at the LA/Torrance (soon to move to Gardena) location because they have filled these low level jobs with minorities. Great move by the senior management at the HQ in Memphis.  They can claim to be a equal opportunity employer saying they have this many minorities in the company and this many minorities in management.  But if you look deeper into the company, you will see the minorities are at the very bottom in job level and pay.  The higher you go, the whiter it gets.  They have minorities in management positions at this LA locations, but these supervisor/managers are just puppets.  They have no authority over anything.  All the decisions are made in Memphis.  Again, don't expect to come in a get a promotion anytime soon.  Prepare to put in years at these wages since there are already many people in line ahead of you.

Experience and expertise mean nothing.  You could have no experience in any given functional department but end up leading that department.  I've never seen anything like it.  It a comedy of errors.

review: Smart marriage of services...not so smart incentives to keep employees sharp and productive.
pros: Great flexibilty in schedule especially if you are a student. Good health benefits.  Worked with and meet the most amazing people! Good opportunity to learn graphic arts software, like Photoshop, Illustrator and good exposure to a variety of software and innovative technology.  Brilliant marriage of 2 needed services by almost anyone who is running any business, espeically small to medium size. Like any marriage FedEX is still working out its communication kinks. Variety of opportunity to move laterally, but limited upward growth.
cons: Try too many new things at once and do not let new concepts stay in place long enough to see if they work. Constanltly moving the target or goal.  Little stability -often reduce hours at will. Sometimes understaffed. Many times 1 or 2 coworkers left to run store with no management or supervisory presence. very little training.  Prior to merger could go online and do training on your own time & initiative - to gain better understanding of design software to bettter service the customer. Now it needed approval and on the floor training is reqularly interrupted, not completed or rushed while trying to service customers. Difficult to learn and master concepts to provide better service and consistent quality product.  Every customer across the nation should experience the same or close to the same level of service and knowledge when they enter FEDEX Office just like they do with FEDEX shipping services.

pros: Good benefits. Full time: you get your hours and frequent overtime (depending on location). Paid time off, holiday (thanksgiving, christmas, New Year), Sick time.
cons:
Not career or skill development oriented. They have a learning plan you and your manager develop but will never allow you to train the skills you are interested in developing. Will not cross train even though you are supposed to be cross trained. Management is childish; lack of communication, lack responsibility, bad people skills. Team members are a mixed bag; some will work others will pass off work and do nothing. Management will let slackers be slackers and place the rest of responsibility on the few harder working employees.

After being in a car accident  outside of work I sustained an injury to an eye and my back. I was going to therapy and returned to work with a doctors not to be placed in lighter work load while I was finishing therapy. I asked if I could switch with a co-worker and work in the business center instead of the parcel center. My manager refused to accommodate me because he didn't have anyone to switch me with. His excuse was that the other team members were female and could not do heavy lifting and that no one in the center is cross trained (referring to team that has been there at least a year and more without cross training).

review: Not for you if you ever want to do more
pros: Pay is good, but don't expect much else.
cons:
With this company being a Fortune 50 company, you'd expect more from it, but don't get your hopes up.  This is the biggest employer in Memphis so they pretty much can treat their employees any way they want and we'd have to put up with it.  The Vacation and Benefits are outdated as compared to other companies of it's size.  Management is great at saying things that sound good without any follow through. All the systems are old and outdated and the one new system they have promoted as a "savior" has landed is the biggest thud in history.   The new system makes our job 5x harder because it just will not work. So we're still being told to work harder even though we have bad tools to work with. 

The sales dept has been allowed the run of the company. They treat everyone they come in contact with horribly and the department has no backbone to stand up to them.  They will consider you their personal concierge.

If you're looking for opportunities to move up. Don't join.  The opportunities here are few and very far between.  There are a bunch of people who are sitting in positions, who have been in the same position for 20 years,  and plan to retire in those same positions, blocking the way for any movement.  You have others that don't want to be here, but are waiting for another buyout to leave.  Even applying for internal positions is very political.  In some cases if you want to even be considered for the job, you have to go and talk to the manager and  kiss up to them  a little otherwise your resume won't even be called for an interview. Even if you're highly qualified.  Most areas would rather fly someone in for a job than promote from within the company.

review: Solid pay and benefits; middling management; work-life balance out of balance
pros: Good pay and benefits; stable (layoffs are rare); many experienced and knowledgeable coworkers
cons: Upper management places burden of achieving work-life balance entirely on the employees, while first-line managers assign excessive hours, weekend work, and/or shift duty to employees; more than a few managers have a supercilious bearing; employees have no power over their working conditions.

cons: The company keeps changing philosophies and just when you get used to following one way of doing things, it all changes.  A lot of people get promoted without deserving it and those who do deserve it get passed over.  Managers are not qualified for their positions, going through mentoring and training after they have the position and in the meantime they have messed things up and blame their direct reports for their mistakes.

pros: Good access to resources, due to the size of the company. Positive brand image. General commitment to core values. The opportunities for community service and the support the company provides after natural disasters help to make the work meaningful.
cons: Career progression is political, rather than skill or merit-based. Overall too confident about its position. Bureaucracy slows decisions; Legal makes the final call, rather than providing counsel. Departure in later years from the core values - but trying to get to basics.

review: Lots of potential.  Check back in a few years.

- Decent benefits.
cons:
- Not treated like part of FedEx, so the reputation of FedEx isn't applicable to FedEx Trade Networks.

- Internal promotions discouraged and limited by policy.
- Low salaries compared to other companies within FedEx family.
- Lack of leadership.

review: Run far away from this place.
pros: The job itself is really pretty awesome. It is always changing, you always are dealing with something new, and always talking to a huge variety of people. You learn a ton of great information that you will know for future jobs.
cons:
Just about everything else. The management is absolutely the worst I've ever seen. The senior manager needs to be replaced ASAP. She is running that place into the ground and has been for years. She is vindictive, manipulative, and will find a way to get rid of you if you disagree with her in any capacity. If you make her mad enough, she'll completely make something up to try and get you fired. The employees there have seen it happen multiple times. Her and the majority of management do not care about any of the employees or their well being. Favoritism is an issue as well. 
The pay is laughable. They try to call the job a call center, though nothing about it is like a call center. They pay low wages because they consider it one, although new hires get hired on now making more than the supervisors even do, or the employees that have worked there for 15+ years. The senior manager is trying to force all the tenured employees out the door so that she can replace them with people that don't question her and are younger and more productive. 
The workload is insane. They have mismanaged things so badly that employees are having to take on literally 4X the normal amount of work, and management doesn't do anything about it because they know that "it'll get done one way or another".  The list goes on and on. Turnover and attrition are at an all time high. People are quitting right and left. 
 Run so far away from this circus and go work for someone who values you. Go work for any other branch of FedEx even.  You will also have absolutely no work life balance. Expect to work massive amounts of overtime because there is so much work constantly.

review: Don't get on this sinking ship. (FedEx Trade Networks, Springfield, MO)
pros:
-Good Benefits, 401K match, benefits day 1 of hire. 
-There are team leads who haven't left yet who are good, caring people- always willing to help. 
-3 of the managers are good people and willing to recognize and admit that there are problems even though their hands are tied because the senior manager is vindictive and ruthless.
-new hires make more starting out than employees who have been there 5-10 years, so that's good if you are starting out although the tenured agents/team leads would disagree.
cons:
-not a good place to work if you like seeing your family. 50 hour work weeks are the norm with no end in sight.
- new hires have no desk to sit at and are forced to sit in a training room by themselves until the next disgruntled employee walks out, freeing up a desk
-new web based systems are being forced on the agents and they crash hourly because the servers aren't strong enough 
-new phone system is a joke. Customers aren't even able to leave a message. Team leads are forced to micromanage employees every second of the day. Literally, you have to specify what you are doing when you get up. If you get up to go to the bathroom, your team lead may be forced to stop what he or she is doing to take a call.
-team leads are stretched so thin that they can't even be expected to get to all of their tasks.
-team leads are grossly underpaid. 
-feelings of hopelessness among leadership (leads and managers) because of how the senior manager is running the place.
-team leads and managers aren't allowed to meet with senior manager's boss without senior manager present. No real feedback can ever be given because of this and it creates a real "keep your head below the parapet" mentality 
-senior manager will lie to make herself look good
-senior manager avoids coming out of her office most of the day
-very few career advancement opportunities

pros: You'll have a job, I guess?? Also, the pay is okay, but only if you press for a good salary.  Work-Life balance is better than other areas at times.
cons: Stagnant, compartmentalized, go nowhere job.  If you want a job that you can sit in for the next 40 years and do the same thing day in and day out, this is the place for You! Management is useless, they will never have your back and cower to sales every chance they get.  You will only get a promotion after working there about 10 years and that will be only if HR makes them because you're maxing out the salary grade.  The only other way you're getting promoted is if you're on project work, but the catch is, they pick the same people (favorites) to do project work over and over.  So don't bet on that.  The work is demeaning and draining every second of everyday!  Sales will literally treat you like dirt under their feet.  They will belittle you, harass you, and treat you down right unprofessionally without repercussions and in most cases your manager will not have your back or defend you or the team in any way. Finally, because of most of the things I've mentioned and more I didn't, we have had a FLOOD of people leaving the department which makes more and more work and stress for the people who remain since they can't hire people fast enough. Even when people are hired, it take at least 6mos to a year to get up to speed in order to effectively help with the workload.

pros: It is the only large cargo carrier in Memphis, Memphis does not have many competing jobs in this category.
cons:
FedEx does not provide adequate benefits to a majority of the employees.  Some Workgroups do have adequate benefits.  The executive management group has an excellent pay, retirement, and bonuses.  There retirements benefits are outstanding, retirement pay, and retirement medical.  

As for the majority of employees the pay is inadequate, the health insurance is sold to the employees for a high price with very poor coverage.  The traditional pension plan was discontinued, and frozen.  They have a very inadequate cash Pension Plan that will pay a minimum token amount when the employee leaves after 20 years.  It is based on your salary and time in service, and applied to a company account every three months with a interest rate of 1% every three months.  That ADDS up to 4% the year, and you do not control the money in the account.  It is controlled by the company.  

Many of the retirees are struggling with the health insurance.  The retirees have to pay $700 to $1,000 a month for coverage for two people.  This is no better than Cobra coverage.  

Many people go to work for large companies for the benefits,  health insurance and retirement knowing that this was promised at the beginning of their employment with this company.  

FedEx is very good with public relations they have the means and the money to make the story sound good.  They also are very good of promising many things.  But to is all smoke and mirrors.

pros: Decent pay, incentives to grow. You must have a knowledge of who's who and network well to make sure you get ahead.

cons: Long hours, Demanding work. Lots of running (kept me in shape, but tiring). No medical benefits.

review: It is a good JOB but terrible unfair company
pros: The workers that actually make the company get along for the most part. Handlers, couriers and pilots!
cons: Pay pay pay and garbage health plan!  The company raises are terrible.  Union union union simply said. How can you raise the starting pay to almost near someone who has been working there 6 plus years? How black are your hearts in upper management? Terrible company and they act like they make no money. Look at all the crap you sponsor! Put money into the people that matter! Union union union union

review: It's part of FedEx but, it's Awful
pros: Become an employee to get your foot into the FedEx brand then move to another Opco where they seem to have things a bit more organized. FTN is a deadend in the FedEx world
cons: Basically you have long time employees hanging on in their positions which clearly have no desire to improve themselves or the company. They started in an office and will end their career in the office and don't really understand air or ocean freight. For a freight forwarder I have never been around so many people that know so little about transportation or even about other parts of FedEx. Middle and upper mgmt don't seem to travel like they do at other forwarders. At other forwarders you will find very diverse team from all over the world even in hourly and intern positions. Well not here they seem to be all from Memphis. They are clueless what markets need attention to grow business and they seem to run both operations and office environments with minimal employees. The next biggest thing for FTN is to grow Air and Ocean to overtake the competition but, they lack the tools, employees, and leverage with carriers to do this. They also want to utilize Fedex Freight to grow their trucking business. I find this strange because most forwarders don't put their focus in the trucking business. They have no TMS system, nor do they plan on getting one, they seem to like do do things manually. They leave positions open intentinaly to save money. Its a company that wants to be global but thinks local. Find something better.

pros: Flexibility & job security is the main reason why people stay at the company. They come in at a lower salary and think that once they get in the door they will transfer or get raises. Raises are based on your salary and incoming employees are not aware of that.

pros: Good pay, opportunities to move up. Flexible schedule. You can start at the bottom and work your way up. Company pays for training.

pros: Decent salary, nice location, some of the people were very nice, the cafeteria food was excellent, that is about all that is good
cons: so as to avoid lawsuits, all discriminatory practices were incredibly subtle; on the surface (e.g., word/communication level), there was no discrimination and allegedly support. However, if you are not African-American (or if you are, but don't "fit"), then the discriminatory behaviors begin. One person was fired because he did not come in to work his shift when he had a 103 fever (proven by a hospital note), even though he had given several hours notice that he was in the hospital. Another was fired because they did not like her clothes (she was harassed daily on her choice of clothing - which was border-line professional: nice pants and a top - and sent home to change until she was fired). I was told to lie on the phone: "tell the customer whatever you have to tell them to get them off the phone". I was not fired, but I was harassed daily, given conflicting instructions from day to day (although I will say that the person "sentenced" to "coach" me started apologizing by the end of day 2 - and it was obvious she was being forced to create a stressful work environment - and it caused her more stress than it did me). All of those fired for "created" reasons (some were fired for legitimate reasons) were white. Those, like me, who were not fired had to "live" with a very hostile environment. One of my friends, a beautiful (inside & out) woman of color, advised me (when I started) to be "invisible - get in, do your work, get out" - hard to do that when I don't have a dark tan.

review: They won't pay you as much as they promise
pros: Good workout if you lift properly
cons: EXTREMELY DANGEROUS. You will definitely get hurt at this job, it's just a matter of when and how badly. It was crazy seeing how intensely some people were maimed working as package handlers. That's why they promise such a high starting rate. However, they will try everything to pay you less than you signed up for. It was ridiculous how many hoops I had to jump through to get the pay I was promised.

pros: People are pretty cool, management on night shift was also pretty cool.

pros: You get a regular paycheck but that is pretty much it. Sometimes they give a freebie like a shirt or a mug.
cons: The job is already stressful.  A trace agent speaks to upset/irate customers all day long, 8-hours a day. It is a division of customer service - but is not customer service.  So you don't even get the nice friendly calls to inquire about services or rates.  You only get the upset customers from calls that have been escalated.  (And the calls are back-to-back ... And you better be on "available" or you have to write an explanation as to why you are not taking calls.) You understand that is part of the job - it is what it is.  However, most of the co-workers are very unprofessional with a fierce, petty, ghetto attitude. Many of them have grown up together and go to the same church and/or live close to each other.  So it is very cliquey. If the non-stop irate calls and the co-workers are not stressful enough, you get no support from the managers.  In fact, they might say they have an open door policy - but that does not mean they are actually willing to listen to any of your concerns or helpful suggestions ... Lest you have a complaint.  They will only preach to you the corporate policies to make you get "on-board" with the program.  Once I had a problem with a manager that kept bullying me.  I mean a manager that treated me like a kindergartner and told me to do things because "she said so".  When I approached the Sr. Mgr. with my concerns, the response was "Let's use this as a coaching opportunity for you".  In other words, the complaint will get nowhere.  So I better shut up and take it.  I realize now the mentality of a large corporation and how management is only there to back each other up.  It's such a shame as I was a hard-working employee that tried to do my best to keep up with the high call volume and consistently be empathetic and helpful to the customers that were in an awful predicament without the delivery of their package.  Other departments at FedEx might be great.  But this particular department has only gone downhill.  It is a nasty cut-throat abusive environment. They expect Trace Reps to be the customer's advocate.  But the management is not there to be the Trace Agent's advocate.  The job is terrible and is always in a "crisis" mode with your taking a beating for FedEx on almost every call.  Yes, that is understood that is what you signed up for.  But the job could be so much more tolerable with sympathetic and supportive managers and less Corporate politics and the ever growing rules that add more burden than assistance to the job/employee itself.  The whole department is a pressure cooker waiting to explode. I would not wish this job on my friends ... buy maybe my worst enemies - Yes.

pros: Work is interesting and great co-workers. Employees treated contractor as another fellow employee, Great group to work with. Very helpful and thoughtful.
cons: A little too much politics in the management levels. Make it difficult for a contractor to do his/her  work. Sometimes it was awkward and caused project to be delay unnecessarily.

review: Run Away! A pittance for the stress and giving away any semblance of a personal life.
pros:
Health benefits 
401k
Vacation time
Holiday pay ‚Äì you work all holidays excluding Christmas and New Year's Day
cons:
Pay ‚Äì Call center wages and is not anywhere near being a call center. 
Call Center ‚Äì NO. Pay is at call center wages but this is no call center. 
Overtime ‚Äì Mandatory excessive and extreme overtime.  
Advancement ‚Äì NO. This is only a job, not a career. There is no opportunity advance. 
Vindictive Workplace ‚Äì Agents cannot speak up or take time off for fear of retaliation.
Favoritism ‚Äì Agents are required to "assist" others to get the work done, not their own work, but someone else‚Äôs work. 
Turnover ‚Äì The turnover is high due to low pay and a high-stress work environment.
Systems ‚Äì The systems are antiquated.

pros: Fred Smith's vision was and is still outstanding.  Unfortunately, it's mostly only his vision now.
cons: FedEx doesn't follow their own code of business ethics policies and procedures, they are not worth the paper or digital media they are printed on, the words are there for the sake of the shareholders and to help prevent lawsuits!   Sales Managers are given free reign to say and do whatever they want about an employee and fire them on the spot without providing any details or opportunity to defend themselves.  At Will employment does not mean that FedEx Managers can break the law and they are.  Harassment, Hostile work environments, intimidation, disparagement and bullying is rampant and even when you report it Nothing is done....Oh wait something is done-the Manager keeps their job and the employee gets fired.  Discrimination violations are rampant and nobody tells anyone for fear of retaliation and HR is a joke(everyone knows FedEx HR is in place for FedEx Management only and going to HR is career suicide).  Unbelievable-it's still the good ol' boys network!

pros: new to the field. The job will allow me to use my strong communication and computer skills with the company.
cons: I been working as a temp . I have coming from the accounting field.  i see where there can be so upgrades,

cons:

cons:
Hours expected to work are stated at the minimum level with finishing times always changing (meaning you never know when you can leave until told to do so)

There are no breaks and no lunches as a part timer (some days can go as long as 8 hrs).

pros: Great workout, you will lose a lot of weight while working at this job, receive basic benefits even though it's not a full-time position, decent pay
cons: Very physically demanding, not enough hours, and the shifts are at terrible times. There is no upside and not many possibilities for growth.
